social_posts.post_text:
Many stories are made up out there that implementing structure, rules and boundaries into your dog’s life will make them misbehave more, or ruin your relationship. And it’s all just simply not true. 

All we see are dogs get BETTER from training while their relationship with their owners becomes stronger. 

Dogs NEED guidance. They don’t come into this world just automatically knowing what to do. And it’s the responsibility of a dog owner to show their pet both sides of the coin. Teach your dogs what you want AND what you don’t want. 

That’s the only way to have clear and effective communication. 

Dogs need the whole story. Dogs need consistency. Dogs need routine and structure. 

Dogs have needs that are vastly different than our own, so it’s up to us to make sure we are truly meeting them. 

Share this post with someone who needs to see it!
Wed night q&a podcast live streaming at 5pm on YouTube and Facebook link is in the bio

So many folks are struggling with Leash Reactivity lately it is incredible, WHY?

It is a combination of false information online from the folks that don’t believe in ever correcting your dog for anything, you avoid all other dogs, these are a couple of strategies that folks have been told to do, unfortunately not one of those things actually stops the unwanted behavior. So this leaves owners struggling and living a very small life as they cannot have their dogs in so many places. 
Folks are going to Reactive dog classes and being isolated from other dogs as they are going crazy with reactivity at the site of people and dogs, they stay there for weeks, sometimes never coming out from behind the screen, like the Wizard of Oz, so 6 classes, 12 classes and they can’t get close to dogs, maybe they can be by a stuffed dog, lol, yep they use those as well of of the most ridiculous thing in the world, lets say a dog attacks a stuffed dog, does that mean you have a dog aggressive dog? So if your dog attacks Uncle Joe’s blow up sex doll, does that mean the dog is human aggressive or is the dog trying to put some dignity back in Uncle Joe’s life. 
Our concept is simple, apply a punisher at the first sign of loading, and yes you do a proper punisher, mark the unwanted behavior with a nice calm NO, and then apply punisher, what do you do, a high level on the remote collar, a firm leash pop on a prong collar, a properly deployed bonker, anything that sucks for the dog that they will want to avoid in the future, So does it create discomfort to the dog? Most likely? but not always, that’s why we use the most effective and efficient tool to stop the behavior. 🔽🔽🔽🔽🔽 continued in comments

All of these dogs struggled with different social issues at one point, but they can all exist because of TRAINING! 

Most dogs actually don’t know how to properly socialize. It is a skill set they must learn 

Imagine going to a get together and one person is running around kissing everyone on the face? Another is pushing and chest bumping everyone. Another is awkwardly following people around without saying anything or introducing themselves?? 

Would all be pretty weird right? 🤣

Same goes for dogs. We need to teach them what’s acceptable and what’s not. 

We actually have to show these guys they have choices, they can move away from other dogs as well as properly interact if they want. But usually they just need some guidance at first. 

After a few sessions with the rules we have instilled, everyone is existing comfortably and harmoniously, and it’s a beautiful sight to see!

We are so excited to be able to share this with you all!

Can’t wait to see you in there 😀❤️

Had to throw it back to this one 🤣🤣

Who’s guilty of this?! 

Don’t let your dog off leash, ever, without a solid recall command. And by recall we mean in the real world, around real distractions. Not just in a sterile training environment.

You never know what life is going to throw at you. Be it deer, another dog, or even a busy road. Your dogs recall needs to be ROCK solid before ever getting rid of that leash. 

Get your reps in. Practice everywhere. And don’t be afraid to drag a long line around for a while until you’re 100% confident in your training. 

A solid recall IS possible, you just might not be practicing the right protocols to get there. 

At some point, corrections for non-compliance of KNOWN commands have to come into play. This is after hundreds of reps of course, but eventually it does need to happen. 

Otherwise you will have a dog who thinks your commands are just optional until the next best thing comes along. 

Our Green to graduate program teaches our exact steps on how we build a solid recall AND all of the other obedience commands like heel, down, and place. 

This program is for every dog and every owner who wants in incredible life for their pet. 

Check it out on our online academy. We have some awesome bundles going through the month of December as well! 🙌🏻

Academy.solidk9training.com

Just a day in the life of a dog trainer 😳🤣

We take NO shit when it comes to advocating for our dogs because scenarios like this are EXACTLY how bites and fights happen. One bad interaction can leave you with a reactive mess of a dog and it’s just not worth it. 

We don’t care if your dog is friendly! We don’t care that you’re a “dog person”. We don’t care that your dog wants to meet every dog it encounters. Our dogs do not, and they actually prefer just hanging out with us and minding their own business. 

If you’re getting charged by dogs on the daily like we are, always try to get your dog behind you and do whatever it takes to avoid conflict/contact. 

It’s tough sometimes but it’s necessary, and don’t ever feel bad about setting firm boundaries to protect your dog.

When it comes to puppies, the list of things to do is ENDLESS!! 

One thing you can start doing right away is getting them used to different textures, sounds and environments. 

We absolutely love our bottle pool and a basic Bluetooth speaker to give puppy some new noises to have some fun with. 

The point of this exercise is to have fun! Make the new things “not scary” to the dog. Use food, praise, and sure a little leash guidance if needed. 

But definitely don’t avoid these things especially at a young age. Dogs who miss out on exercises like this as puppies sometimes become a bit nervous as adults and spook easily around noises or in new environments. (It’s not because they had a bad experience either) it’s because of lack of exposure 

This exercise will not only build your dogs’ confidence, but it will help them learn to overcome fear and learn to explore situations rather than flee. It’s really beautiful watching these little guys figure it out and the immediate sense of gratification they get after ☺️

If you just got a new puppy or are thinking about it this holiday season, our puppy course is currently bundled with our green to graduate program! $100 savings ‼️🎉

We will walk you through the journey of bringing home a puppy. From crate training & potty schedules, all the way to obedience, confidence building and grooming skills! 

It’s a one stop shop for raising an incredible dog. And it’s bundled with our best selling course for a limited time, so you can have the dog you always wanted. 

Academy.solidk9training.com

Here’s a great success story from someone who purchased our puppy course. 

They have been following the training since the day they brought their puppy home and are well on their way to having a well adjusted and balanced dog. (Puppies grow up fast, don’t forget you’re raising a DOG)

Every day they have been exposing this pup to noises, different environments, using her daily food for training, and doing everything else we suggest. 

This all builds confidence and patterns very good habits for the long term. 

You don’t need to wait until the dog is “x amount of months old” to begin training… you can start the day they become a part of your family. 

Puppies who begin training from a young age benefit HUGE because they grow up understanding expectations and boundaries. 

Super proud of this family for doing the work and being SO proactive with a new puppy. 

It’s such a great feeling! 

👉and don’t forget our puppy course is currently bundled with our green to graduate program. The puppy course blends seamlessly into GTG so when your puppy outgrows the foundational stages, you can jump right into e collar and off leash training. This combo is the ultimate pair that will give you massive success with your dog! Buy them together and save $100! 🙌🏻

Odin is with us down here in Florida in our VIP board and train program. He lives with us and our dogs and goes on daily excursions like this. 

Odin also struggles with leash reactivity so we figured this would be a great way for him to get exposure to other dogs as well. 

Odin is learning impulse control, how to be calm and relaxed even in stressful situations, and most importantly he’s learning how to stop whining (a major issue according to his owners) 

Odin absolutely crushed his Santa adventure and we even have the picture to prove it! (Watch til the end!) 🎅🏼 

If you want to see the behind the scenes and how we troubleshoot in settings like this- become a subscriber for only $4.99 a month. We post content like that daily with our training dogs

As big of a mouth as I have when it comes to actually training the dogs I am quite silent, I put in a lot of default behaviors and levels of expectation for the dog.

This is s clip from a video we made almost 10 years ago and it is a short part of “Stop your dog from pulling on the leash in 5 minutes” we talk about the default sit when you come to a stop, we also expect dogs to stop at thresholds, to not bolt out crates or into crates, same with vehicles. So many things we train the dog for we train with standard reward based training, then we take away the word, and we correct for not complying, this is a great leadership exercise in general. 

These are great exercises to build a great bond with your dog, a wonderful relationship and to really get your dogs attention and be valuable for the dog.

Duke has made some serious progress with his car anxiety. 

It was so bad that his owners couldn’t take him anywhere at all and had the vet come to the house to spare them the car ride. 

Imagine owning a dog that you couldn’t even take on a simple car ride to the park, or to the hiking trail?  That’s NOT how life with a dog is supposed to be. 

We worked on this with Duke for a few sessions and now he’s able to calmly ride in the car without practically causing an accident. 

Your dogs behavior in the car might be something you don’t think about often, or the fact they do behave you might think every dog is that way, but we typically see the worst side of every behavior. 

Duke’s car anxiety was literally making his and his owners’ worlds so small. 

We’re excited that we got Duke over this hurdle and he will be able to experience so much more out of life moving forward.

Remi just went home after her six weeks of training with us. She was super reactive toward kids although she’d already been through training prior to us as well. 

The missing component in this recipe was the human training. Remi’s owners needed to learn HOW to actually work their dog through her thresholds and how to hold her accountable on their own. 

Remi also got some much needed exposure to kids throughout her stay, but most importantly her owners gained the confidence they needed to handle her in these situations. 

Super happy for this family & we are so proud of them for putting in the work!

We hear it all the time. “The dog wouldn’t be so reactive if it knew how to heel properly.” “Just train the dog a better heel to stop the reactions.”

If only it were that simple!!

The truth is, the majority of our clients come to us with dogs that have already been trained. They DO know heel in a training ring and in the real world. Their owners have spent thousands on training, and their dog has amazing obedience…until.

Until that dog across the street barks, or the cat comes rushing out of the bushes. Then all that obedience can be kissed goodbye as owners are white knuckling their leashes and hoping for the best. (Sound familiar?)

And then think about how many times you have taken a walk and seen dogs zig-zagging around their owners, sniffing, and walking 5 feet out ahead, but they’re not reactive. Those dogs certainly don’t know what a proper heel command is, but they know how to BEHAVE on a leash. 

Are you catching on yet?

That’s because leash reactivity actually has nothing to do with obedience. Your dog can have the cleanest, tightest heel in the world and still be leash reactive. Why? Because behavioral problems and obedience are not the same. Behavioral issues are usually a symptom of a breakdown in leadership between dog and owner. 

Leash reactivity usually manifests for many reasons. The number one reason being your dog was attacked by another dog on the walk, so now it’s always on the defense. Another reason is because they simply just grew into the behavior and were never taught that it wasn’t acceptable.

Dogs can lunge on the leash for ANY reason, but they continue the behavior because their owners have never given them a reason not to! It’s really that simple. 

CONT in comments! ⬇️

Many folks struggle with outdoor behavior, leash pulling, barking at people/dogs, redirecting on owners, not being handler aware, trying to attack dogs and people, constantly whining on the walk, always sniffing. Car behavior, barking out windows, pacing back and forth, panting and stressed out. Off leash the dog never listens to commands, has no recall and has no handler awareness. 
All these things concern us as owners and we do our best to make it better, first you need to make sure you are using the right tools, training, philosophy and actually understand how to train behaviors as well as stop behaviors. 
It starts in the home, are u challenging your dog, are u working your dog above threshold, are u asking your dog to do much, are u putting in rules for your dog, are u making your dog work and not just free roam, I’m not just talking about thresholds and waiting for food, but rooms they can go in and rooms they cannot, not rushing doors and windows, no resource guarding of anything, no stubbornness or selective listening. 
Training your dog to a higher standard, which to us is minimum standard. A good example is our Green to Graduate program on our academy which all owners can do on their own. We make things valuable in the house and us being relevant, it will help u with all outside work as u are becoming more and more relevant to your dog and your dog actually starts believing you, listening to you and u actually have a better relationship.

Angelo working our board and train Odin! Odin is going home tomorrow and a great way to gauge a dogs progress is to see if an inexperienced handler can work them successfully. 

Angelo has become our “training proofer” to test Odin’s skills, and we’d say he’s ready for the go home 🙌🏻

In the last couple of weeks we have gotten thousands of new followers, WELCOME! To Solid K9 Training.

We specialize in the behavior rehabilitation in dogs and there is not a behavior we can not work with, we also do a lot of owner education as well with their dogs so they can be successful. 

Of course we do all basic training to a high public access level around lots of distractions along with the rehab work we do.

Between all of our free social media, on IG, Tick Tock, Facebook and Youtube, as well as 6-7 podcasts a week for Q & A we have a Patreon Page that has a Zoom Room Q & A live each week. 

We also have wonderful online courses so you can fully off leash train your dog even without ever hiring a dog trainer. We offer online coaching as well.

In the next couple of days we are giving away a wonderful online course Walk the Walk that shows you step by step how to get an awesome walk, so look out for that and how you can sign up.

Thank. You all for being part of the SK9T family

Jeff

This is a clip from a old video about teaching a dog to walk on a leash in less then 5 minutes.

When you get a dog with unknown background folks often think, believe and repeat the worst possible situation and then rely on that to move their training forward or historically stagnant or backward all because of a story that most likely is false, and often made up on purpose to pull at your heartstrings.

I can’t tell you how many fearful, nervous, anxious, shut down dogs we get in (they arrive that way) and with our training program and philosophy they excel. Why we don’t believe the old story, we say, hey here is a dog with this set of unwanted behaviors and is lacking in these wanted behaviors. So its time to start training what you should be doing, stop what you should not be doing, finding your motivation for both and move forward.

Yes there is lots of troubleshooting involved in the process, which can take some time, breaking through old patterned habits, stop allowing to owner and the dog to play victim, getting through all the objections the dog makes which if you don’t you further the made up story.

Its time to rewrite the story (someone else most likely wrote the original sob story anyway) I am not discounting dogs have not had a hard life, well it is what it is, when is the dog going to break the cycle and who is going to teach the dog how to.

YOU can, what’s stopping you?

Potato went home after six weeks with us working on his reactivity and aggression issues. Potato has bitten people in the past and was just generally a VERY insecure and nervous dog. 

We gave him a solid obedience foundation and a ton of exposure that he’d been lacking to people, dogs, and the world. 

Unfortunately when dogs struggle with behavioral issues, it becomes harder and harder to get them out, when that’s really what they need the most. 

Potato learned to work through his limiting stress thresholds and was able to gain a lot of confidence throughout his training. 

The more we brought him out and held him accountable for his training, the better he was able to become. The reactivity and nervousness went away because potato learned that 

1. He will always be advocated for 
2. There is a certain expectation of behavior now 
3. The world really isn’t so scary, he just needed to experience it more 
4. His owners are more confident with their own skill set from the training they received as well 

It’s never just one thing that rehabs a dog. It’s a thousand small things that snowball into a well balanced and well behaved family pet. 

We are so happy for Potato and his family. Their life is about to be so much bigger together!

Odin went home yesterday after our two week board and train here in Florida. Odin was already HIGHLY trained by his owner. He had off leash obedience, lots of tricks, focused heel etc. But Odin was completely reactive toward other dogs. So bad that he’d even react to dogs without breaking a heel or missing a stride. But it was all causing his owners a ton of anxiety when it came to taking him anywhere. 

Odin was actually attacked by another dog which caused this issue in the first place. Like we talk about all the time, it’s probably the MOST common cause for leash reactivity that we see. And that’s why we are so adamant about not allowing strange dogs to interact with ours- because we see the worst of it historically. 

Regardless though we worked Odin through his issues and on top of that have his owners the confidence they needed to get this behavior under control. 

We spent 2 hours on the outskirts of a dog park yesterday and Odin absolutely crushed it. His owners are excited to take him back out to coffee shops, stores, and actually make him a part of their every day life again. 

Leash reactivity is not only damaging to the dogs state of mind, but it effects the humans as well. Nobody got a dog to leave it at home when they could be a part of things. Training has given Odin and his owners their lives back, and we are so happy for them.

Families like this are the exact reason why we created our virtual leash reactivity courses. So that people all over the world struggling with these issues can still have a well trained and well behaved dog. We show you every single method and step on how to address this behavior and train what you do want- for the long term. Our online courses are changing so many lives. Academy.solidk9training.com

Thanks all of you for sharing your experience and the struggles you face with off leash dogs as well. This is a major problem with so many folks -
Just a day in the life of a dog trainer 😳🤣

We take NO shit when it comes to advocating for our dogs because scenarios like this are EXACTLY how bites and fights happen. One bad interaction can leave you with a reactive mess of a dog and it’s just not worth it. 

We don’t care if your dog is friendly! We don’t care that you’re a “dog person”. We don’t care that your dog wants to meet every dog it encounters. Our dogs do not, and they actually prefer just hanging out with us and minding their own business. 

If you’re getting charged by dogs on the daily like we are, always try to get your dog behind you and do whatever it takes to avoid conflict/contact. 

It’s tough sometimes but it’s necessary, and don’t ever feel bad about setting firm boundaries to protect your dog.

No matter what tool you use or do not use, it is  very important that your dog understand how to behave even without tools. We want dogs to be under voice control, even off leash. Tools though are wonderful communication devices. The issue is using the correct tools, philosophy and training is important to get the results you want. Unfortunately training a dog on a harness which is designed for the dog to pull, think of sled dogs, protection work etc. it actually encourages the dog to pull as a natural response to being held back on a harness.

Lots of folks are using harnesses since they don’t pull on the dogs neck, which makes sense. What makes more sense is not having the dog pull at all, so training a dog to not pull and walk in a proper heel can be done pretty quickly and efficiently, using a prong collar as well as a remote collar can make a huge difference, especially with handlers that are not as skilled or softer of a handler. It is a wonderful leverage tool.

Bottom line you still need skills to teach your dog to properly walk, a harness though is going to make it very hard for your average pet dog owner. The whole concept of what my company stands for is to make the life of an owner easier, to get results in a much timelier way (since why drag it out) and so both dogs and owners can have a better quality of life.

Lots of folks bringing home dogs this holiday season, no matter  how many times I encourage folks to not get a holiday puppy, folks still do. So we can help you if you decide to go that route,

The biggest thing to remember is to be prepared, have all of your training tools, your food, your crate, a potty schedule, your exercise schedule, your training schedule planned out. Study up on all of the different stages that your puppy will be going through, keep all the affection in check. Puppies are cute, every dog killer and human mauler I have ever worked with (and that’s a lot) started out as a cute puppy, so remember you are raising a dog and not a puppy. A dog that within in months is going to give you a run for your money and will stress you out if you are not prepared, even if you are prepared it will stress you out so be ready.

Make sure everyone is on the same game plan and everyone is following the rules and the routine, puppies and dogs thrive on routine, spend the first 90 days with a solid routine, then it becomes habit.

Be knowledgable about what is acceptable and what is not, be careful of the thinking “they will grow out of it” and “let dogs be dogs” 

I would highly encourage you not to get 2 dogs at once and just focus on one dog until it is trained up nice before you make that decision. 

We have a great puppy course if you need some help we have a great combo course bundle, it is our puppy course and our Green to Graduate course, if you follow this you will have an incredibly trained dog that will be under off leash voice control by 6 months of age, but it is never to late to start.

It is becoming so cliche for folks to say “clicker training doesn’t work” well, that is an incredibly false statement. It is said by many dog owners who did not get results, sort of like saying hammers are useless for building a house, well, what are you trying to use the hammer for? Building the frame or installing the plumbing.

There are a couple of factors involved, where you actually taught and coached as to how to clicker train? What are you trying to actually train your dog to do?

We use a reward based system to train all of our wanted commands, awe also use markers when it comes to all dog training. A clicker is a marker, it marks when the dog does something you want, correct positioning, behavior etc, it is used after the behavior is done, not to do the actual behavior, so when your dog is not sitting, downing, or recalling you should not be clicking away like a remote control hoping the dog does the behavior, you are actually marking the unwanted behavior.

So I would encourage you to all learn how to properly clicker train, there are many videos on this online, if you choose not to use one that is fine, you will still need to learn how to train a dog to do wanted behaviors. 

IF you are trying to stop unwanted behaviors well, then you are not using a reward based system and your clicker is not going to be a good step one, that is when you need to learn how to apply a punisher (that’s a different story on another video)

Off leash recall with Enzo! This guy has come a LONG way with his training. He used to be super pushy, rude, would jump up and bite at his owner while on a basic walk. 

Enzo has learned to respect leadership and follow direction. With our training program we not only address obedience but we work on the dogs state of mind as well. 

A dog that is obedient but has no problem growling or biting a person is not a trained dog in our book. We want it all. 

So we peel back all the layers and build a new foundation for the dog to grow with. 

Enzo is a much more respectful dog these days because he understands what the expectations are. No more free for all and getting away with whatever he wants. The structure and accountability actually have made him a much calmer, happier, and more balanced dog. 

We teach all of this in our Green to Graduate program so that you can train your dog at home the same way we train dogs in our program. The course takes you step by step so you can go at your own pace. It’s our most complete training program and it’s changing the lives of humans and dogs all over the world. 

Check it out here: academy.solidk9training.com

It is so important that dogs both learn how to do behaviors that we want them to do. I would like to think that is a given, what commands we want them to do in the real world in high level distractions.  Teach your dog proper manners and behavior. Feed a good diet and exercise your dog. Train your dog to a high level that you can and look for help to get there.’

Even more important is to teach your dog how not to do certain behaviors, all your unwanted and dangerous behaviors. You can’t get away with avoiding it. You will have a life of misery and not being able to take your dog to as many places as possible, have whoever you want your dog to not struggle with anyone folks coming over your house. 

So many people struggle with this concept, you can avoid it but it will end up in a pretty miserable life and possibly the end of the dogs life, we teach you how to  properly stop unwanted behaviors. Most of the information is free for the taking, between videos and podcasts the answers are there for you.

We put up lots of content on our platforms and we get lots of comments, one of our videos of us body blocking dogs from both on leash and off leash dogs, rushing us and our training dogs (who are with us for rehab and the most important thing is to advocate for them), an off leash dog attacking your dog can set your stable dog back months or years, we see it all the time.

Folks love to let us know that if we ever did that to their dog (keep in mind no contact is made in these videos, but if your dog does come at us and make contact I assure you we will make contact back with intent to neutralize the situation).

So if you where walking down the street and 1-3 dogs came at your dog (to just say hello according to the folks that threaten us) and they started attacking your dog and you, possibly your child if they are with you. What would you do? Would you just stand there and watch or would you do whatever it took to keep you, your child and your dog safe? What would that look like? How about if that was videotaped and put up online of you in action for all to see, then all of a sudden your dog because highly leash reactive to the dogs even 20 feet away, then 1 week later, an off leash dog came running at you and your dog, what would you do, would you just hope for the best? Would you be proactive and neutralize the threat? Would you advocate for you and yourself and your family? How about if that was videotaped and put up for all to see?

The thing is we take the videos and we put them up, and they help many people and you can tell by the comments what a big issue this is, so if you have not had this happen to you, you are fortunate, if it has and it turns out bad, I have feel bad for you and your dog, but on the other hand we can help you with the rehab, so today, you hate us and want to hurt us and when you are in our situation you want our help, since we are really good at what we do. So think about these thing before your fingers start typing on peoples pages just because you are not in the same situation.

This is a clip from an older video, there are many training collars you can use on your dog to communicate, personally whatever works for you in an efficient manner. A prong collar which does not hurt a dog is an incredible collar to start with if you are struggling with your dog.

No matter what tool you use or do not use, it is  very important that your dog understand how to behave even without tools. We want dogs to be under voice control, even off leash. Tools though are wonderful communication devices. The issue is using the correct tools, philosophy and training is important to get the results you want. Unfortunately training a dog on a harness which is designed for the dog to pull, think of sled dogs, protection work etc. it actually encourages the dog to pull as a natural response to being held back on a harness.

Lots of folks are using harnesses since they don’t pull on the dogs neck, which makes sense. What makes more sense is not having the dog pull at all, so training a dog to not pull and walk in a proper heel can be done pretty quickly and efficiently, using a prong collar as well as a remote collar can make a huge difference, especially with handlers that are not as skilled or softer of a handler. It is a wonderful leverage tool.

Bottom line you still need skills to teach your dog to properly walk, a harness though is going to make it very hard for your average pet dog owner. The whole concept of what my company stands for is to make the life of an owner easier, to get results in a much timelier way (since why drag it out) and so both dogs and owners can have a better quality of life.

Apparently sticking our feet out to create boundaries and advocate for ours dogs is *also* wrong 🤣

Even though that other dog appears friendly, why is it wrong for us to block it from running up to our dogs faces? 

Both of these board and train dogs are working, holding command, doing their jobs, and it’s not the time to socialize. 

We allow them to socialize (go look through our feed and youll see both of these dogs happily playing with other dogs) but we don’t want them interacting with unknown dogs at a pet store. 

When we take dogs out in public it’s for them to practice being calm and under control. 

If we let them just run up to every person and dog they meet, all our training would be pointless.

Especially since these two are known to be reactive on the leash, the last thing we want is a free for all breaking out in a store. 

Public outings, for us, are get the dogs exposure through existence. Not direct interaction.

Everything has its time and place, but the stores and public settings, to us, is a time for the dogs to be calm and neutral.

If you want your dog rushing everyone it sees, go for it. But when dogs are under our care and control, we will always advocate for them and stop interactions like this from happening in public places.

Socialization is so misunderstood by so many people, they feel they have to have their dog meet every dog and every person, we look at things a little differently in order to have a very well rounded and confident dog.

Its all about exposure, exposing your dog to as many environmentals as possible, that means sights, sounds, smells, surfaces, people, dogs, textures, weather, sensations on their feet, climbing over, under and through things. Putting your dog above threshold and working your dog through it.

If you want your dog to thrive in the real world these things are so important, so many folks are holding their dogs back from living the best lives. I understand why, many people don’t know how to work dogs through stress, we intentionally create stress for the dog so we can then teach the dog how to handle it, therefore raising up the dogs stress threshold. It is the same with people and personal growth, if you want to live in a bubble, not take chances and risks, not get out of your comfort zone, then you are going to struggle in many things.

We have so many videos online, we discuss it on our podcast and we talk about it in our social media channels and on our 1/1.

If you’re new here, welcome! If not, you’re probably familiar with our e collar training program that involves 3 major stages: continuous Stim (escape conditioning), NCS (non compliance stim on working levels/ also known as the early avoidance conditioning phase) and lastly, corrections which are also avoidance conditioning but that’s the very last step after we’ve done thousands of reps with a dog in their obedience. 

The NCS stage is basically our bridge between escape conditioning and corrections. We need to teach the dogs HOW to go back to command once they’ve come out of it. 

We use this middle ground to do all of our proofing. Our silly noises, throwing food on the ground, talking to the dogs like we know our friends, family and even strangers would. We actually WANT dogs to make mistakes in this stage so we can show them what to do afterward. 

In this video you see stella step off “place” and her trainer Jan engages the remote at her WORKING level, a 7, Stim is on continuously the whole time and we slowly dial up until stella is back on place. 

This makes it super super clear for her that if she breaks command without being released, she will feel slight remote communication to guide her back. 

She also gets rewarded for figuring it out on her own, and you see once january role plays this situation again, she stays put! 

Stella is learning to AVOID the stimulation of the remote, and also wants to stay in place longer because that just = more rewards. So it’s a win win. 

We will do this with tons of distractions in tons of environments until stella no longer needs any guidance from her trainers at all. SHe will eventually either not break command  at all, or run back so quickly we barely have time to engage the remote. That’s a good tell that she is ready to move on past NCS and onto her final proofing stage of corrections.

We always follow this sequence when training dogs as if you miss a step, it’ll lead to a lot of confusion for them. We want our communication to be as clear and concise as possible. 

We also share our e collar training system in our Green to Graduate Course on our online academy! Link in bio!

Many of the dogs we get in for training come to us with a host of issues. From anxiety, nervousness, to aggression and fear. 

Every single dog benefits from confidence building training, as it’s a crucial part of our rehab program. 

Many dogs display bad behavior because they are under socialized, under exposed, and lack an underlying sense of confidence. 

We give dogs a ton of obedience but we also focus a lot on confidence building as they go hand in hand when it comes to creating a well rounded and better behaved dog. 

You don’t need fancy equipment to do this either. You can just take your dog to a local park or into the woods and have them jump over things, go under things, and through things

Work your dog THROUGH their fears instead of avoiding them. You’ll see them grow in ways you never thought possible.

We often get asked “what does structure look like?” When it comes to our dogs. Structure just means routine. Dogs like routine and guidance, just like humans do when we’re trying to figure out new things and form new habits. 

Here are a few ways you can begin adding more structure to your dogs life, which will lead to better behavior all around. 

👉Crate training- this will give your dog a safe space of its own and allow you to practice some separation from your dog. Boundaries are important. 

👉Scheduled potty times to help your dog learn bladder control and to break up the day 

👉Make training a part of your lifestyle by not just doing little drills. But have them hold downstays at cafes with you, or hold place while you get work done. Train for your lifestyle, not just a choreographed routine. 

👉Hand feed/train with daily food to give yourself some value to your dog. Have your dog earn its food and it will be that much more motivated to train with you. 

👉Structured walks will help transfer your leadership role to the outside world as well. And it’s a great opportunity to also practice obedience along the way. Break up the walk with some recalls and downstays, too. 

👉Play time and engagement games can be broken up throughout the day as well. On your terms, whenever you want. 

👉Practice duration on commands inside the house so pattern calm behavior indoors 

👉No free roaming the house until your dog can make good choices on its own. Sometimes our dogs need more “management” in the beginning. And that’s totally fine. This is a marathon not a sprint. Give your dog LOTS of guidance when you’re first starting out to build that muscle memory. 

Share this with someone who might need help training their dog! 💯

Six myths you’re being told about dog training:

1. “Some dogs aren’t meant to heel on a leash”

2. “Crate training is cruel” 

3. “Remote collars will ruin your relationship with your dog”

4. “Some dogs are not receptive to corrections” 

5. “You can’t train older dogs out of bad habits” 

6. “Tools are just a shortcut” 

These all couldn’t be further from the truth. We have worked with so many breeds that are always labeled “untrainable” aka Huskies, Beagles, Dachshunds, Akitas, LGDs, and pretty much every breed in between, and we have yet to see one that has not benefited from training. 

We use crates, remote collars, food, clickers, prong collars, slip leads, martingales, muzzles, leashes, head halters, and basically every effective tool that is available because when a proper communication can be established with your dog- EVERYTHING changes. Not every dog needs the same tools, the same amount of hours put into them, but they ALL thrive with clear communication and leadership. We are open-minded and use whatever is effective with the particular dog we are working with. We want the dog to succeed for its own good, not just our own agenda. 

Training tools are often deemed “short cuts” for some reason. Which is interesting because they can get the job done in a much clearer and effective way, but somehow that is a bad thing? Don’t we all want our dogs trained up as efficiently and quickly as possible so we can actually get them out into the world with us? The truth is, when your approach is working, it shouldn’t take forever  to train your pet dog basic obedience. You’ll get into a flow real quick when thinks are clicking for you both 😉

Every dog of every breed and age learns through reward and punishment. That’s how nature works. Every action in life has a consequence, either positive or negative. When you really break it down that simply, you’ll realize that dog training isn’t as complicated as it seems. And no matter how old or practiced a behavior is in your dog, you can absolutely work on it and make it better. Will it take a bit longer for some behaviors that are YEARS in the making? Sure. But not impossible by any means.

We recently put up a video of a before and after of a dog going nuts in the car. Barking like crazy going back and forth, jumping over seats etc. The dog would be triggering on everything it saw, which made for a pretty crummy car ride as well as a dangerous situation.

If you struggle with this it can be extremely simple to stop, first thing you need to do is teach your dog what you do not want, you need to stop the barking, then you can move onto you need the dog to lay down and relax. This is the teaching the dog the whole picture, what to do and what not to do and you increase what you want and decrease what you don’t want, its a 2 way street in our world.

A shock collar (remote collar) is a highly effective tool for this, you can start out by doing this at your front door or windows if the dog does that, you will be saying NO and then apply the punisher in a nice calm way, no yelling or screaming, just calmness and direct to the point. So yes it becomes uncomfortable to go nuts in the car. 

You can also either after or parallel teach the dog to do a great downstay around distractions, get the dog up t correction level so your dog understands there is consequences for not holding command. This is teaching your dog both sides of the story, eliminate a behavior and increase a behavior, we do both, we want the dog to have a full understanding of what is expected and what is not allowed

The out command is one of our most versatile commands. It can get a dog to drop a toy, back away from a resource, or even give another dog or person space. 

In this video you see Stella getting a bit too pushy with her greeting. We like to abide by a 3 second sniff rule. 

So once Stella has overstayed her welcome, the out command gets her to back off. This is a great way to start introducing dogs who have never met before. Set those boundaries from the start and make sure they are enforced. 

This creates a sense of safety and trust with the dogs knowing the humans are advocating for them. It also helps teach proper social skills as the dogs typically learn to move away without a reminder with enough repetition and practice. 

Does your dog know a solid “out” command?

This dog is trained on a remote collar. Can you tell?

When it comes to remote collar training, we prefer to use the tool as a supplement to the training we have already done. 

Every dog that goes through our training program learns a solid foundation of leash work and hundreds if not thousands of reps  creating a positive association to the commands. 

We bring every dog to verbal compliance on all their commands before a remote collar is introduced for their obedience. We want to be sure the dog truly knows what we want before adding in a second language. 

Once the dog knows their obedience, we then  layer the remote collar as this allows us to communicate with the dogs off leash, at far distances, and around even the highest of distractions. We have to basically re-teach them their obedience on the remote. It’s an additional step, with a few hundred more reps to teach the dog what we want in this context as well. 

A remote collar is nothing but an incredible supplement to the training we have already done. It gives a huge reliability factor, and by the time these dogs go home, the collars become a “just in case” tool. 

They are not being used constantly nor are they “needed” to get the dogs to listen. Dogs make mistakes just like humans do. So we like to have these tools in the rare instance a dog decides that the squirrel, bird, or other dog is more important than their obedience in a specific moment of time. 

If we want dogs to enjoy off leash freedom, it’s our responsibility and obligation to make sure they are RELIABLE. 

If you want to learn how to use the remote collar, how to condition it, and how to train with it- we spell it ALL out for you in our Green to Graduate program. We created this course so dog owners just like you can have a fully trained dog without even needing to hire a dog trainer.

Stopping your dog from pulling really doesn’t need to be an overly complicated process. 

All you need to do is teach your dog the concept of yielding to leash pressure (you can do this with any kind of collar you choose, but prong collars will make it much easier for you especially if you lack leash handling skills. We use slip leads most of the time, but do whatever works for YOU)

Once your dog understands to follow the leash vs pulling against it, you can then just use small pops to direct your dog and communicate to stop pulling. A popping motions tends to work better than pulling/dragging your dog. (Dogs tend to want to fight against that kind of pressure) 

& Don’t even worry about a perfect heel right off the bat. Just stop the pulling!! 

And if your dog happens to get out ahead of you, stop walking, pop the leash, and turn around if you need to. 

Teach the dog that following and staying close to you is the best option. 

But you can’t do any teaching until your dog at a minimum understands the basics of pressure and release on a standard leash. 

Don’t skip your foundation work, and be sure to make your communication with your dog as clear as possible.

The majority of basic obedience and stopping of unwanted behaviors in family pet dogs is extremely simple.

It is not a guess, it is not luck it is not just naturally happen, you actually have to have a plan of action for your dog. The great thing is there are many documented plans of actions already in place and no reason to reinvent the wheel.

Keep in mind, that most trainers do not show how to stop unwanted behaviors.

Always keep in mind that you reward what you want and you correct what you don’t want. The big thing is finding the motivation for both and that’s the troubleshooting part of training.

Dog training takes reps and reps and reps, correct timing of rewards and corrections. The question is what do you do if a dog does not take the typical rewards such as food, you need to understand leash handling skills and compulsion training as many dogs don’t care about what you think is a positive motivator. 

If you are looking for a wonderful program on how to fully off leash train a dog from a dog that does not even know one command. Our Green To Graduate program is available at academy.solidkitraining.com

so We received this comment on our YouTube video on resource guarding yesterday… 🙄

Have you ever been told the “swap” method to stop resource guarding with your dog? 

Unfortunately that advice is being given all the time, and all it does it lead to a dog that continues to guard, and typically ends up guarding worse. 

The problem is that you might get the dog to drop whatever it has in the moment, but what happens if you need the thing you swapped for? The dog will guard that, and the cycle only continues. 

Also, think about the fact that the dog is guarding and you’re technically presenting a REWARD while they’re displaying this behavior. You’re reinforcing a terrible state of mind—most likely unknowingly. 

The way to STOP resource guarding is by correcting the behavior with an intolerable consequence. Whether that’s a leash pop, squirt bottle, remote collar, or bonker—a true correction is whatever the dog perceives as a correction. 

Many people say “well I tell my dog no and put it in the crate, but the behavior happens again the next day.” That’s because kenneling your dog isn’t a correction (and we highly advise you DONT use the kennel as a correction, as it should be a positive experience for the dog) YOU might view the crate as a correction, but if it’s not changing the dogs behavior, chances are the dog doesn’t care. 

We stop resource guarding ALL the time. It’s actually very simple to accomplish and takes us typically no more than a few seconds. Resource guarding is a very dangerous behavior and often leads dogs to being put down or rehomed. 

It’s never a good outcome either way. That’s why we work so hard to ensure dog owners can extinguish this behavior on their own. 

We have dozens of free YouTube videos on this as well as an entire course on resource guarding on our online academy.

Every single dog you see in our social media in public crushing it, started out learning the basics. 

We proof all dogs’ obedience indoors before they ever step foot outside. We role play scenarios and we teach them what we want as well as what we DONT want. (They need to know both!)

We solidify their obedience around as many distractions as possible so that way when it’s time to go in public, these dogs know exactly what to do. 

Throwing a ball and having your dog hold command might seem like a pointless training protocol, but it teaches impulse control and that commands are non negotiable. This carries over to the outside world as well.

That’s why when people ask “how do I improve my dogs behavior on the walk?” Our answer is always “what’s the rest of the day look like?”

Your dogs indoor behavior is JUST as important as their outdoor behavior. It’s all connected!

Remote collars get such a bad rap but all we see are dogs living bigger, better, and more fulfilled lives through training. 

Do either of these dogs look “sad” or “shut down” to you? Ironically enough they both came in pretty nervous. They lacked direction Which led to a lot of insecurity which manifested as bad behavior. 

That’s the thing that is typically misunderstood with remote collar training. It’s easy to label them these horrific tools that “shock your dog and inflict pain”, but in reality they are just the most clear and effective communication you could ever have with your dog. 

You just need to understand how they actually work. Remote collars are giving so many dogs freedom and clarity. They are the farthest thing from a danger to your dog. 

Jake and June are perfect examples. Two dogs who just didn’t know what was actually expected of them—and now they’re thriving with some rules and boundaries, and massive amounts of freedom!

Uhtred is with us for our VIP in-home board and train down here in Florida. He is one year old and one of his owners goals is to get him into dock diving, which requires him learning to swim. 

As part of our in home program, we can do this since Uhtred is living with us. Today was his first ever swimming lesson. 

At first he was of course hesitant, but we work him through it and after THREE reps he was absolutely loving the water and going in 100% on his own. 

This is how quick you can get dogs over fear. We don’t counter condition this, or carry the dog around, we just show him that he’s capable of doing it. 

We take the fear away by allowing him to learn for himself that the water is actually an enjoyable experience. 

Dogs usually just don’t understand the mechanics of swimming at first so we keep a leash on to keep them moving and to help them level their bodies out. 

Once they realize they do, in fact, have back legs— the swimming becomes seamless and FUN! 

Super happy for this guy as his next endeavors in dock diving will be incredible for him.

We all know place is great for dogs to keep them out of trouble in the home, but it’s also GREAT for their state of mind. 

So many dogs just don’t know how to relax. Ever. It’s actually something they need to be taught. 

Place is THE command to do that. Think of it like meditation for your dog. At first it’s hard because busy minds don’t like to slow down. But after enough practice it becomes a staple in their routine. 

Dogs actually end up loving place because they know it’s THEIR safe place to go relax and not be bothered. 

It’s one of our most utilized commands in pet dog training for a reason. 

Place is for indoor behavior. Off leash zoomies and fun are for the outdoors. And it’s ok to teach your dog BOTH!

We get messages all the time from Frenchie owners specifically asking if it’s ok to use a prong collar on brachycephalic breeds. 

And the truth is prong collars are actually one of the safest collars for these breeds and they do NOT allow the dog to choke, no matter what. 

Prong collars have safety stops that prevent them from constricting the dogs neck like a slip lead or choke chain would. 

Prong collars actually make it so that you only have to use the LEAST amount of pressure on the dogs neck.

Honey the Rottweiler is with us to learn some basic obedience. 

When dogs get to a certain point in training we start what is called the “proofing” stage. 

This is where we start asking more of the dog around distractions and sometimes even switch up their handlers to make sure they’re really understanding things. 

Dogs often listen better for their primary handler (you see this even in your own home most likely) so exercises like this help the dogs understand that their training is non negotiable.

We are frequently asked why Wes wears his @rexspecsk9 goggles. It’s because he has pannus- an eye condition that requires UV protection so that it doesn’t progress. 

We LOVE our Rex specs so much & conditioning them was so simple. Just like muzzle conditioning basically. 

You use high value food and begin with a lure just like you’re training any other behavior. When their nose is inside the googles, mark this with “good” or “yes” & let them eat the food. 

Once your dog masters this step, you can begin naming the cue whatever you want. We use “goggles” 

Next step is phasing out the lure and adding your word first with a little bit of latency to let your dog start thinking about what the word means. 

Word first. Then help with food if they need it. 

Now your dog will eventually start responding to the word on cue, and you can of course reward AFTER they commit to the behavior and you mark it. 

It’s a process, but if you make it fun your dog won’t mind it one bit!

Honey learning to recall off high distractions! What’s more of a distraction than some loving from the kiddos? 🥰

When it comes to recall we proof this command off everything imaginable❗️ 

We want dogs to recall the first time every time no matter WHAT is going on ✅ 

It makes a difference when you have other people to help you out when you’re beginning training because it’s easy to think your dog has a “perfect” recall when it’s just the two of you. 

Bring your dog out into the real world and watch how quickly other things become more important. 

That’s why we focus SO much on building up our commands around real distractions. 

We proof dogs off of toys, food, other humans and other dogs. We role play scenarios that would truly happen in day to day life, not just at our training center. 

We talk to them in high pitched voices. We allow them to make mistakes so we can teach them what to do instead.

When it comes to training your dog, it never really “ends.” You and your dog just become better equipped to handle whatever life throws at you the more practice you have. 

*notice Honey is on a remote collar but it’s NOT being used at all in this scenario. Honey is under verbal compliance and the e collar is only used if she doesn’t listen. Which is very very rare. At this point in training, she’s basically listening to the cue every single time*

Gus is a new b&t who is dog aggressive and also needs to learn his obedience. Whenever start out a dog it all begins the same way. 

Basic leadership skills:
-leash work/pressure release
-kennel drills
-threshold work
-spatial pressure/claiming space 

It’s not until the dog masters the above skills that we start obedience. 

We find that starting out with some basic leadership work helps everything else vs going straight into obedience before we establish a relationship. 

Gus will be with us for six weeks and is already making huge progress

If you’ve been following us long enough you’ll know we NEVER advise going to dog parks.

If you’re struggling with your dogs behavior/training, there might be a few pieces to the puzzle you’re missing, as most dog training programs fail to address the following:

-every interaction with your dog is training, not just the 5-10 minute sessions you do throughout the day 

-your dog’s indoor behavior will carry over to the outdoors i.e. barking at every human or squirrel that passes by

-YOUR behavior plays a role in your dog’s behavior i.e. do you let your dog break commands whenever it wants to? Are you giving out love and affection all day and never asking your dog to do much?

-food training only goes so far. Its great for building a foundation, but eventually there will be things in the real world your dog perceives more valuable than food. I.e prey!!!

-duration work is POWERFUL for the dog’s state of mind. You need to address the mindset to achieve a fully calm & balanced dog

Coco is with us for our board and train program in Florida. She’s a 10 month old Doberman who’s experiencing some insecurity and random fears. 

Her owners want us to work on solidifying her obedience as well as giving her more confidence. 

Since coco is living in our home, we are noticing some random fears crop up and one of which was the vacuum. We vacuum daily with dogs in the house (sometimes multiple times a day) and coco kept acting nervous and breaking her place command to run from the vacuum. So instead of avoiding this issue and just kenneling her up we worked on it. 

Believe it or not, you CAN get dogs over their fears  fairly quickly. 

In just one day we were able to get her over this. And this one thing will carry to over to MANY other things

It’s never just about the vacuum. It’s about the dogs underlying lack of confidence in general. Teach them how to overcome one obstacle and see how much better they do with the next one. 

It’s a compound effect and such a simple exercise that anyone can do. 

Coco knows place, so all we do is correct her when she breaks and reward when she doesn’t. Eventually she just figures out that staying in command is the better choice, and the sky isn’t going to fall when the vacuum gets close to her

It’s time to toss all those negative beliefs about your dog out the window

Your dog *IS* trainable, your current methods just aren’t working

No dog that we’ve ever worked with has been “untrainable”

Unmotivated with well established bad behaviors? Sure. But definitely still trainable. 

Most the the dogs we have trained were at one point labeled “hard headed”, “stubborn”, “defiant.” But all we’re seeing are dogs who lack a clear communication system that actually WORKS for them.

Putting labels on your dog only creates more of a story to hold onto, and those stories keep you stuck.

What about instead of calling your dog “untrainable” you said “my dog just lacks clarity on his/her expectations.”

Because that’s really all dog training boils down to. Does your dog understand the expectations, have you taught those expectations, and are you consistent with those expectations?

Any successful training program should (at a minimum) include the following:
-a reward based system to create positive associations with your commands
-a consistent marker system 
-a clear communication system
-corrections for unwanted behavior/non compliance of known commands 

Once you have this recipe to follow, the rest becomes SO much easier on you and the dog.

It’s through this very simple system that we are able to fully off leash train dogs and create SOLID reliability in their training. 

It’s how we have helped so many people all over the world. We keep it simple!

When you actually look at the dogs we train and rehabilitate with remote collars, you see that they are actually 10x happier than they were when they initially came to us.

Every dog that we’ve ever trained with a remote collar ends up as a better version of themselves.

These dogs understand what true freedom feels like. 

These dogs learn that the world is much, much larger than the 4 walls of their home.

This is a very typical day for us. Unfortunately we are constantly being approached my random off leash dogs whenever we take our training dogs out in public. 

Whether our dogs are friendly or not (this dog *IS* our trainer just says he’s not to create come urgency) they deserve to have their space respected by people and other dogs. 

Our training dogs are all with us for a reason- to learn rock solid obedience and public access skills. Not to be harassed by random dogs where there are leash laws in place. 

Even in a bathroom stall we can’t escape this nonsense. In a public store, where dogs are absolutely required to be on leash, we have an off leash dog actually walk right into the stall. 

God forbid this actually started a dog fight while our trainer is sitting on the toilet. 

Many dogs, even friendly dogs, could become defensive in a scenario like this where they know their handler is preoccupied. 

We don’t sit around and wait for 💩 to hit the fan. We take the proactive approach and de escalate the situation before it happens.

We have just started a new VIP Board and Train Real World program in Florida for a new program we have created for your dog to be able to do more adventures with you and to live the dogs and your fullest life, training your dog to be able to go where you want to take your dog. Since we just moved to Florida and even though I have been in business for 20 years and traveled the world doing close to 300 seminars and helping people around the world, I can’t take that for granted starting a new business in a new city 2000 miles away.

Its like starting all over again mostly, so it is important that the folks who want to hire me fully understand what we do, how we train, the tools we use, our prices, our programs, and get to know us through the powers of social media before they even call us, it is important that the trainer and the client gel since you are building a relationship. The training of the dog is the most laborious part, but the training of the owner is the most important part and can be the most difficult part. 

Before there is even a transaction made you want the potential client to know as much about you as possible. Then if the dog owner does call you (we have them fill out a form first) then we call them, we can discuss more about the issues, more about the level of expectations, figuring out what program is best for the dog, establishing the after care, training and protocols that you will be doing to give the owner a better lifestyle that the owner and dog can enjoy.

Clover the gsd puppy is with us in RI learning how to be a reliably trained dog. She’s only 8 months old and was a bit insecure when she got to us. Nervous around scooters, bikes etc. 

The nail dremel was another thing we needed to condition her to. Nail maintenance is so important for dogs, so it’s a skill set we teach every dog in our program. 

Believe it or not, you can have a dog that’s calm and relaxed for nails quicker and easier than you think!

We see and my colleagues are seeing more and more anxious, stressed and fearful dogs then ever before. When you do a board and train and spend 24/7 with the dog for 6 weeks it lets you into the window of their mind.

We strive to increase the dogs confidence, destress the dog (also teach the dog how to deal with stress in truly stressful times), raise the stress bar so simple things don’t stress out the dog. 

To many peoples surprise a remote collar is a wonderful tool for this, WHAT “your shocking my fearful dog” and that makes it better, well I guess that’s one way to look at it, what I can tell you is that just about every dog we see and that’s a lot of dogs, has had stress, fear and anxiety created by rewards, yep they have been rewarded in a positive way for that state of mind.

So how does it work, well we leverage obedience to help the dog incredibly quickly, most folks even trainers don’t know the incredible things you can do for a dog and their state of mind. How do you start, well have the dog go into a known command like a down (in our world down means downstay until they are released) then present the fearful thing, vacuum, doors opening, different sounds, running kids etc…if the dog breaks command you correct the dog for breaking command, so you are not correcting the dog for being afraid or stressed, you are correcting for breaking a known command. Then very quickly the dog settles in nice, falls asleep and does not care about the distractions, in a way they are forced to face their fears head on with your guidance and we see dogs get over long standing stressors in minutes.

If the dog is always whining or doing OCD behaviors, the remote collar stops that, both things lead to a dog just then laying down into a calm state.

The dogs do not shut down, it does not make it worse, all we have ever seen is the dog get better and better, a calmer dog, a more confident dog, a better relationship with the owner.
Our favorite activity when the weather is perfect 🙌🏻

This is a great example of no free passes for unwanted behavior, the dog in this story is doing an intentional unwanted and potentially dangerous behavior that can lead to a dog fight, we see it all the time, with guarding behaviors. So yes  handicapped or not the dog in question needs to have a punisher applied to stop the unwanted behavior. The great thing about situations like this is you have the opportuntiy to teach a couple of things, first you teach that guarding is wrong (we have a resource guarding course) and then you teach the OUT away from (insert anything ), that way you can also at anytime send your dog away from something instantly, you can do it with multiple dogs and it has so many uses and is such a practical command and is not just used for guarding behaviors. 

Our goal is to have better behaved dogs and dogs that start thinking on their own and making better decisions overall and we see this over and over again. You end up with a much better relationship with your dog, a better communication lifestyle with you and your dog and the freedom to do so much once they understand the rules of what is expected and what is not allowed…it is quite awesome.

Our trainer Courtney walking you all through her protocols before the walk *with a dog that is semi-new to our training program*

The walk begins well BEFORE you think it does. Your dogs inside behavior will absolutely carry over to the outdoors. 

That’s why we set the tone before we even step foot outside. 

Important things to note before you begin the walk:
1. Is your dogs energy/arousal super high when you break out the leash? 
2. Is the dog building anticipation at the door?
3. Is the dog whining or shaking out of excitement? 
4. Does your dog bark at everything that passes by your house? 

^^^ if you answered yes to any of the above, but you’re struggling on the walk, these are ALL things to start working on before you even focus on the walk itself. 

Once you’ve gotten your indoor behavior under control, you can now go outside and work your thresholds, driveway drills, and get your dog in the right headspace for an amazing walk!

We often get comments on our social media about how we are “extreme” and we should “let dogs be dogs”

Our response is always “you don’t know until you own THAT dog”

Once you get THAT dog, everything changes. Once you get THAT dog, your entire philosophy on training & the way you look at dog ownership might change. 

This person, had the same revelation once she got THAT dog, and kudos to her for sharing her experience. 

Many people think that because their dog is friendly all dogs must be! Their dog is friendly so the unfriendly dogs MUST tolerate them. 

Unfortunately that’s living in a fantasy land. The owners with reactive dogs are the ones out there busting their asses to train their dogs and keep them safe. So if they seem “extreme” it’s because they have worked damn hard to overcome the issues that are typically caused by “friendly” dogs charging them in the first place. 

So next time you think about passing judgement on someone for how they choose to advocate, live, train their dog…. Put yourself in their shoes first. 

Your reality isn’t everyone else’s reality.

Gus the golden retriever is with us for his issues with other dogs. 

He would get too amped up during play and it would quickly escalate to aggression. 

We have taught Gus how to control his impulses a bit more around other dogs. 

We also advocate for him in every social interaction so that he’s not bullied or pushed around by other dogs. 

This increases his confidence knowing that things are under control and not a free for all. 

Dogs, just like humans, feel more secure knowing there is a strong leader in charge. Gus knows his trainers will never let things escalate to the point of a fight, so it allows the dogs to be more relaxed and at ease in these situations.

Welcome Steve!! This guy has quite a bite history with both humans and dogs. He has made many attempts to bite all of our trainers so far as well, but within a couple of days we are seeing a newer, softer side of Steve. 

Many dogs come to us with these same issues. They’re often deemed a “lost cause” or “untrainable” but the reality is no one has ever communicated to the dogs in a way they understand. 

Steve has only been with us a few days but we have made some drastic changes already. 

We give him massive structure, rules, boundaries, and we also spend our entire day teaching Steve what IS acceptable behavior. 

When a dog has true clarity on what’s expected of them, everything changes 

But it’s up to US, the humans, to teach these dogs what we actually want. 

To leave them guessing or to figure it out on their own would just be unfair. 

Super proud of Steve and the team for all the incredible progress so far

Clover the gsd puppy is with us basic obedience, but we noticed this farm dog has lots of random fears cropping up. Could be her age, could also be just isn’t exposed to city life often. 

Whatever the case, we work her through it and build her confidence in the process. 

By giving Clover exposure to different textures, noises, environments, and showing her it’s fine, she learns to get over her irrational fears. 

The last thing we want is her growing into an adult dog that’s afraid of a leaf blowing in the wind. 

Desensitizing your dog from a young age is critical to their success as an adult dog. 

This stage is sooo important.

Whenever we talk about the “out” command, we talk about its many uses. 

We use out in so many ways:
1. To get dogs to move out of our space 
2. To get dogs to release a toy from their mouth 
3. To get dogs to release food or a high value resource and move away 
4. To get dogs to move away from other dogs 

Even though it’s the same word, we teach it in a few different contexts and the dogs understand what it means in each scenario. 

The “out” command is probably our most utilized command aside from recall. It keeps so many dogs safe and in their homes, when they previously might have struggled with resource guarding. And even if they didn’t, it’s still such an important skill to teach every dog.

Our free content is helping so many people all over the world. 

We try and make the process so simple for everyone for a reason. 

Most dog owners don’t want to become masters of dog training. They just want a nice family pet who can go places with them. 

Most owners want the process to be simple. So simple their four year olds can participate. 

Messages like this make us SO happy 🥰

Nothing better than seeing a dog being fully involved in its family’s life and everyone being able to enjoy each others company. 

That’s what this dog training thing is all about for us. 

So much is possible when you find the right help. 

Our free resources are by the thousands on YouTube, and if this is possible with our free trainings, then imagine what’s possible with our paid courses!

Dog training, to us, means fitting the training into your lifestyle. 

Once your dog knows it’s basics, it’s time to work on duration and holding commands in real world situations. 

Coco, who’s with us for board and train, knows all her basics. It would be sort of a waste of time to keep running her through basic drills just for the sake of “training”

Instead, we work on building up her skills she knows. 

We have her hold her commands for longer periods of time, around higher distractions, and with less and less leash guidance. 

This is how we get dogs to become fully off leash reliable. 

We are always progressing them with every training session, even it doesn’t feel like “training” 

Just living life with Coco is training. And that’s how we want you to live with your dog, too!

People often ask us since we teach a very strict heel command, as well as work on eliminating leash reactivity. Folks will ask us, when does the dog go to the bathroom, do they get any free time so Ill let you know the short of it.

We potty dogs before and after the walk, but we also will make planned potty stops, usually just one per hour, dogs usually are marking when you think they need a pee break they are just marking and that is just not necessary during a structured walk.

When on the pee break, we stop at a grassy spot, plant our feet tell the dog to go potty, don’t let the dog drag you around, keep in mind if the dog is on a 6 foot leash and if I can recall from school, they have that 6 feet times 3.14 feet in a circle around you which you should have enough room, it also helps you with getting your dog to peeing on command which is a fantastic skill for your dog.

😂 we kid, we kid (kinda) 

The truth is, MOST dogs can be trained to be off leash *reliable*. 

*there is a difference between off leash and off leash reliable. And yelling “they’re friendly” as a dog charges towards other people/dogs doesn’t cut it for “reliable”…sorry 

A remote collar trained dog is probably the closest thing you can get to a FULLY RELIABLE off leash trained dog. 

And we often get comments on our page saying “if the dog needs the collar, then it’s not trained” 

But this statement couldn’t be further from the truth and only shows the ignorance of the poster. 

Dogs that are remote collar trained should eventually get to a point where they no longer need the collar. They are under full voice control 100% of the time. 

They’re under voice control around distractions and every environment they go to. 

But just because they’re trained, why would you take the collar off? 

You never hear people asking “when can I take my dogs leash off? Or when can I take the flat buckle collar off?”

It’s only with the e collar that people make this statement. 

But we like to live life with dogs knowing we are prepared for the unpredictability of life. 

We know we have that control in our back pocket if we need it. 

We also put our seatbelts on in the car every time *just in case* 😉

A dog wearing an e collar isn’t a sign of lack of control. It’s actually quite the opposite. 

E collar trained dogs have freedom

E collar trained dogs have HUGE lives 

E collar trained dogs are reliable 

And that’s why we will always be talking about this tool and educating the masses.

There is a time and a place for growling, barking, pulling etc….during play, when playing tug of ward with your dog, I allow growling, barking, pulling etc….I actually will growl back, it is a game and as long as you can start it and stop it on command, it is very healthy to do and a great confidence building and relationship building with your dog.

As strict as we are when teaching obedience and stopping unwanted behaviors, we do a lot of fun things with our dogs, biking, running, walks, swimming in pools and ocean, running in fields, hiking etc.

So time and place and context, can your dog growl, yes and no, why is the context.

We can’t stress enough the importance of teaching your dogs duration work (holding commands for extended periods of time)

Duration is the first thing we get to once a dog knows it’s foundation.  With duration, you can then introduce distractions and distance, and make the duration even better. 

Notice Courtney is working four dogs at the same time because each of them is able to hold command while the other is actively doing drills. 

This is how we are able to accomplish so much in a day, because even while dogs are lying down seemingly “doing nothing” it’s still training! 

Our dogs are technically working “all day” but they do get rest breaks where they lie on place and just hang out for a while. 

These skills transfer to home life when their owners want to take them out to restaurants, etc because they are able to just chill and ignore every thing going on. 

Don’t forget the importance of duration work!! 

Once your dog knows it’s stuff, it’s time to start asking more from them

Walking your dog should be the BEST part of your day. Not the worst. 

Here are a few tips to get your dog into a great headspace BEFORE the walk, so you can start out on a good note instead of chasing that bad behavior all the way around the block. 

1. Your dog should wait at all thresholds patiently before heading outside 

2. Address any whining or frantic behavior before you step out 

3. Practice your obedience in your driveway to get your dog into a follower mindset. 

4. Only start the walk when your dog is calmly complying. 

Sometimes your walk might just be up and down your street for twenty minutes. 

It’s not about the distance, but the QUALITY of the walk 

Training is training- don’t rush and have a crappy walk just because you “need to go the distance” 

If you’re struggling with getting your dog to walk nicely, don’t worry. You’re definitely not alone. It’s probably the #1 issue dog owners come to us about.

Henry and Gus are both at the point in their training where they are ready to proof it all in the real world. 

Every dog reaches a point in their training where they need to get out of “kindergarten” and get into the world. 

Public access skills are baseline skills that every dog in our program learns. 

We want them to be able to remain neutral around pretty much everything, and there’s a reason that they can. 

That’s because by the time we get to this stage of training, these dogs have practiced their commands around distractions INSIDE thousands of times before we ever step foot in a store. 

We are teaching them what do if/when they make mistakes and how to avoid making them altogether. 

We spend a couple weeks teaching these skills before the dogs are put into more difficult situations such as stores and cafes. 

We want dogs to win when it’s finally time to be in the real world, and in order for that to happen, we need to make sure our foundation is strong.
