We often get comments on our page that say “the dogs are only listening because the dog is wearing a prong collar”

This is always an interesting statement because SO many dogs we train come in on tools and still behave terribly, pull on the leash, etc. the tools don’t automatically train the dogs. 

Dog training trains the dogs, the tools just make the communication CLEAR!

Take Pippa for example. This little 30lb cocker spaniel came in for board and train on a prong collar, and she was still pulling like a race horse. 

She did not care about the prong initially. And If it was inflicting that much pain, don’t you think she’d stop pulling? And it’s not just Pippa, we see many dogs that do this same thing. 

Dogs aren’t dumb animals. If something truly hurt, they’d likely try to avoid that sensation, not cause more of it. 

We are huge advocates of tools, but we know that tools still require training. Slapping a collar on your dog won’t get the results you’re looking for. 

You still need to train the dog and find the most effective way to communicate with them. 

And then put in lots and lots and lots of repetition to make it a patterned behavior. 

Curious to know what your experience has been with tools, what you’ve been told about them, and how they’re working for you? Let us know in the comments!

Three tips for a better walk:

👉 train a rock solid heel INSIDE & around your house first, don’t be in a rush to get down the block

👉 proof your heel just like any other command. Add in distractions and teach your dog that there are consequences for breaking command. A good example is throwing some food on the ground and asking your dog to heel around it without going for it. If your dog can’t pass this test, they definitely can’t handle the real world yet, so keep working on it. 

👉 when on walks, it’s best not to allow your dog to greet every dog/person they meet. You want your dog to be neutral on the walk. Allowing them to become excited and aroused every time they see another living creature only reinforces this state of mind. Keep it neutral whenever your dog is in “heel”

There is SO much more to the walk, the list is almost endless.

A rock solid walk doesn’t need to be THAT difficult to achieve though. 

And that’s why we are hosting a LIVE mastering the walk masterclass TOMORROW 3/2!!

Sign up at academy.solidk9training.com

Don’t forget to proof your obedience as much as possible before ever leaving your house. 

The proofing stage is where we teach dogs how to troubleshoot when they make mistakes. 

So often this stage is skipped because it appears the dog is doing “so well!” But then take them to the outside world and their training falls apart. 

We make things difficult for these guys before ever going into the public scene so that they can learn how to handle a bit of stress and what to do when they are. 

The real world isn’t going to care that your dog is a bit nervous or fearful. Cars will still pass by, dogs will still bark and lunge at them, and kids will always be there being loud and having a good time. That’s just life. 

We teach dogs how to remain calm in these situations INDOORS so that when the real thing happens, they know exactly what to do. 

Spend time on this stage of training. It’s worth it to have a dog that knows what to do instead of freaking out at the first bit of uncertainty.

Rainbow “bo” learning the place command! 

Notice the first few reps we do, Jan isn’t naming the command right away. This is because we don’t want to immediately add a word just in case the dog struggles or refuses to get on the bed. 

Think about it: you say “place” and the dog resists. What are you really teaching the word “place” to mean? 

So we don’t name a behavior until we know for certain the dog can do it. 

Then you see the last few reps Jan begins naming it, because Bo is doing such a great job. 

All of our training starts this way. Whenever you see an off leash dog at a go home, just remember it started like this. Hundreds and hundreds of reps. Slow and steady.

Are you struggling with a leash reactive dog? 

Or maybe your dog WAS reactive at one point and you’ve made some major progress with their behavior. 

Or maybe your dog just doesn’t like other dogs in it’s face. Do YOU like strangers coming up to your face? 

Whatever the reason, it’s always ok to advocate for your dog. ESPECIALLY when they’re in public, training, or in a vulnerable position like a downstay. 

On leash greetings, (nose to nose greetings at that) are the worst way to go about socializing dogs. 

We’ve just seen it go sideways too many times, and to us, it’s just not worth it. 

When dogs are in public it should be expected that they walk on leash and remain under control. 

There’s no need to be meeting and greeting every person and dog while on an outing. 

Dogs get plenty of socializing just be learning to exist and be neutral around others dogs/people, and they gain trust in you when they know you’ll keep them safe. 

Mini here is a friendly dog, but it doesn’t matter. We’ve seen friendly dogs snap or get defensive when strange dogs rush them or get in their face. It’s just rude behavior in general. 

We always post videos like this because we want to show you how simple and non confrontational advocating for your dog can be. A simple foot out to the side is typically enough to create ample space.

Bo is with us for reactivity to the door and just reactivity in general to a lot of things. 

We address all the behaviors inside just as much as outside. 

So If a dog struggles with a certain issue, we work on it until it’s no longer an issue. 

You can start this process by having your dog just in their crate or on their bed. Play doorbell noises on your phone, knock on tables, etc to simulate the noise as much as possible. 

Correct any nonsense until your dog can calmly relax. 

The next step is to move on to the actual door. Have friends role play this or try it yourself. Same rules apply. Correct nonsense and reward when they start catching on and remaining neutral. 

We try and desensitize the dogs to this scenario as much as possible when it’s a big issue at home for them. 

And if you still want your dog to give an alert bark or two, you can. Just add a marker like “quiet” or “no” before correcting the barking. Don’t just correct the barking. 

This way the dog will always wait for your verbal cue to stop, and they won’t think barking in general is unacceptable. 

Share this with someone who’s struggling with door issues!

Bruno the GSD is with us at our Florida VIP board and train for a few reasons:

He was super selective with what commands he’d listen to and when. None of it was reliable, and his owner wanted the off leash freedom *which requires 100% reliability!*

His heel was very pushy. He was always jocking for position and trying to be at least a foot ahead of you. This only fueled his leash reactivity even more. A dog out in front is just looking for things to react to instead of focusing on their handler. 

It’s been 9 days and Bruno is transitioning to more off leash obedience. We are gaining more and more trust in him and that he will actually follow through when asked of something. 

The first few days with him were actually interesting because he has had prior training, but he ignored 99% of it. So this meant every word we tried to teach, he already had his own association to it which was “I don’t listen to that word” 🙃

We just took it slow, worked BACKWARDS and started all over again. even though he had been trained prior, it wasn’t to the standards we want because his stubbornness had allowed his commands to be come very diluted.

It’s all starting to come together this week, and the next step is getting him out into more real world environments vs just the neighborhood!

🤣🤣 sometimes it’s not worth explaining.

We’ve never seen a dog properly trained on a remote collar or prong collar become “afraid” or “shut down”

They get excited to work because it means it’s time for freedom, time for fun, time to go places. 

Don’t let the fear mongering hold you back from your best life with your dog. 

Use whatever method makes the most sense to you. 

Just make sure you’re actually meeting your dog’s needs and not just your own.

When you take your dog in public, it should be expected that your dog is well behaved and under control. So many dogs are on leashes, yet their owners have zero control over them. They’re being dragged all over the place anyway— so what purpose is that leash really serving?

There is a certain skill set dogs should possess when going into busy places or public stores, events etc. At a minimum, the dog should be able to walk nicely and stay with its owner. 

And if you’re dog is going to be off leash, it should absolutely have RELIABLE recall, and there are no excuses for that. Shouting “my dog is friendly” as it comes barreling towards us, doesn’t make a difference. The dogs WE take out, on leash, and have under control might not want a dog crashing into its face at full speed. It’s a recipe for disaster, and if you’re dog can’t recall, don’t take it off leash. Period. 

We also have a lot of people who think it’s their personal right to touch anyone’s dog they choose. They never ask, they just do. And it’s honestly one of the most rude things you could ever do. 

Thats like walking up and touching someone’s ass or their kid. Why are dogs any different? It’s called basic respect. 

ASK permission for dogs to greet and to touch them!! 

This video is just three clips of encounters that happen to us DAILY. It’s really time to raise the bar with our behavior and our dogs. 

Does this stuff happen to you all, too? How do you handle these scenarios?

The biggest lie out there when it comes to stopping leash reactivity is “redirect the dog with food or toys so it will stop.”

But anyone who understands how dogs actually learn knows that presenting food or any kind of reward WHILE a dog is displaying an unwanted behavior only reinforces that behavior. 

We train obedience with MASSIVE positive reinforcement, we counter condition behaviors with MASSIVE positive reinforcement, but that’s when the dog is already making good choices. 

That’s our step two. Step one involves actually stopping the unwanted behaviors with a correction. A split second correction is often the one thing missing from many training programs, and it’s the ONE thing keeping your dog from being its best self. 

Leash reactivity is becoming a huge problem for so many dogs and owners around the world. We work with dogs like that every single day and successfully stop the behavior for the long-term. 

Despite what the internet might tell you, you won’t damage the relationship or make your dog hate you. In fact, telling your dog to cut the shit once and for all will HELP your relationship. 

I don’t know about you, but walking a well behaved dog is definitely better than a lunging, out of control one.

When we talk about state of mind training, this is exactly what we mean. 

Notice the difference in these two dogs. Both in a “down” command, but in VERY different places mentally. 

If we continued to let Bruno whine (which we didn’t it was addressed) he would have kept cycling over and over until he eventually would break command and jump on the picnic table (something he had tried to do a couple of times during our outing when this was filmed) 

The point being—just because a dog knows it’s obedience, doesn’t mean it has good behavior. Bruno is trained, he’s a police dog washout so he did have training prior to coming to us. 

However, he only knew how to go, go, go. He was never taught how to turn it off and just chill out when told to do so. 

We aren’t in anyway “taking away his drive” but we want him to be able to control it a bit more. 

An anxious, cycling dog isn’t good for the dog or for the owners. Mental state is everything. And it’s often the “thing” missing from most training. 

We don’t usually have dog owners ask us “make my dog more crazy!” We get the opposite “hep my dog relax so they can come places with me”

So, the point of this video is to hopefully give you all something to chew on. It’s a great visual about what we talk about so often when it comes to state of mind & why we stress it so much.

When your dog is leash reactive, it’s SO important you understand the timing of your corrections. 

Most folks wait too long, like In this video. The dog does a perfect example of what we call “loading” AKA the hard stare down BEFORE the growl and BEFORE the lunge. 

Most people say “there was no sign” because they’re missing this very important split second of behavior. 

Most dogs actually don’t growl or wait a few seconds to react like this dog in the video. They go from a hard stare to a lunge or bite in a split second. That’s why when people say “don’t correct the growl, it’s important communication” that’s usually not helpful information when dealing with dogs like this. As many dogs don’t growl at all, or the growl quickly escalates into a full blown reaction. 

You need to be aware of your dogs subtle cues like this dog in the video. That stare, the body language, THOSE are the signs that we so clearly pick up on because we work with dogs like this every day. 

You should correct this loading behavior BEFORE it escalates as that will give your dog the most clear communication. If you wait too long, your dog is already too aroused or “too drunk” to care what you have to say. 

The timing of this is so important, and it’s often what owners are missing time and time again. 

Let us know if this video was helpful to you in the comments below! And share this with your friends who need some help!

We often talk about the fact that dogs needs are very different than our own. 

For starters, dogs need a lot of exercise and mental stimulation. 

Of course they need food water, shelter etc. the list goes on. 

But a solid training and exercise program are close to the top of the list in our book—especially for our working breeds. 

Right now we have a total of 5 working dogs under our care. 2 GSD, a mal, and 2 Dobermans. 3 of them are intact males and one an intact female. 

They’re in a highly structured environment to keep the peace among them all, they’re being trained daily just through the way we live our life with them: quiet in the kennel, downstays or place while we work, heel when we walk and recall during any off leash time. We aren’t running drills with them. We are LIVING with them. We are holding them accountable for things they already know. (We’ve trained them all)

Then we exercise them hard a few times a day to meet their needs in this area as well. 

It doesn’t need to be an overwhelming process to have multiple dogs, but it does require some strategy and effort to make it work. 

But Training your dog is powerful as It makes living with them and doing things with them so much more enjoyable. 

Imagine running 3 out of control dogs on a bike 😂💀

This is why we stress training so much. It opens the door to what’s possible in so many ways.

We currently have a few boarding and training dogs here for the week. *we do board past clients in Florida just fyi!*

And one of the things we do is keep them in a highly structured environment and stick to routines for everyone’s sanity.

At night the dogs know the drill. Out the door to the yard and back in to the kennel. 

It’s a routine that happens every night around the same time, and it never changes. This basically puts the dogs on autopilot mode and keeps the entire thing seamless. 

From start to finish it’s about ten minutes. 

You can be doing this with your own dog at home too. It definitely doesn’t need to be a big “to do”. Just keep it consistent and the dogs will pick it up just like anything else. 

Are your dogs in a structured potty routine? or is nighttime outing more like a free for all zoomie fest with lots of chaos 😂 

Let us know in the comments ⬇️⬇️

Car etiquette is a major protocol we work on with all dogs. Why? It’s a huge safety issue. 

Every dog we train eventually ends up off leash trained, which means they’re in the back of a car either in a crate or just lying down, and when that door opens the last thing we want is a dog flying out into a parking lot or street. 

We treat the car threshold like any other entry/exit. 

The dog should always wait to be released. 

Bruno had a really bad habit when he first got to us of FLYING in and out of cars and bullying his way through most thresholds. We had to stop that immediately since it was a safety risk. 

Now he knows to wait calmly for the next thing to do without any chaotic energy. 

This is where your public access training begins— in the car! 

Don’t wait til your dog is already out of control to address things. Start it as early as the vehicle. 

Your dogs state of mind will carry over to your next destination when you address it early in the process. 

Share this with someone who needs help with their car rides!!

Don’t take this the wrong way, but most dog owners do not need any help giving their dogs MORE affection and love. 

Most dog owners come to us with out of control dogs who are creating mayhem in their lives. 

Too much freedom, lack of boundaries, affection at the wrong times, these are all the recipe for an entitled, pushy dog. 

And this typically manifests with aggression or other unwanted behaviors. 

The first thing we talk about with our clients is “what’s the rest of the day look like?”

Are you holding your dog accountable? Enforcing rules? Correcting for non compliance or bad behavior in general? 

When the balance is off, so is the behavior and the relationship historically. 

Our clients love their dogs, of course!!! But dogs need more than love when it comes to living a balanced life within your home.

so We received this comment on our YouTube video on resource guarding yesterday… 🙄

Have you ever been told the “swap” method to stop resource guarding with your dog? 

Unfortunately that advice is being given all the time, and all it does it lead to a dog that continues to guard, and typically ends up guarding worse. 

The problem is that you might get the dog to drop whatever it has in the moment, but what happens if you need the thing you swapped for? The dog will guard that, and the cycle only continues. 

Also, think about the fact that the dog is guarding and you’re technically presenting a REWARD while they’re displaying this behavior. You’re reinforcing a terrible state of mind—most likely unknowingly. 

The way to STOP resource guarding is by correcting the behavior with an intolerable consequence. Whether that’s a leash pop, squirt bottle, remote collar, or bonker—a true correction is whatever the dog perceives as a correction. 

Many people say “well I tell my dog no and put it in the crate, but the behavior happens again the next day.” That’s because kenneling your dog isn’t a correction (and we highly advise you DONT use the kennel as a correction, as it should be a positive experience for the dog) YOU might view the crate as a correction, but if it’s not changing the dogs behavior, chances are the dog doesn’t care. 

We stop resource guarding ALL the time. It’s actually very simple to accomplish and takes us typically no more than a few seconds. Resource guarding is a very dangerous behavior and often leads dogs to being put down or rehomed. 

It’s never a good outcome either way. That’s why we work so hard to ensure dog owners can extinguish this behavior on their own. 

We have dozens of free YouTube videos on this as well as an entire course on resource guarding on our online academy.

Yesterday we helped a client who was struggling to get her dog into the kennel. She would turn and snap at the slightest leash pressure. She also wouldn’t take food and if the owner tried to throw food inside, Charlotte (the dog) would just reach her head in, grab the food and run away. 

We are huge believers in the crate because we know how important they are for the safety of the dog. Charlotte was already beginning to rip up papers and books while her owner was in the other room etc, so some household management was definitely needed. 

Charlotte also gets very car sick, so being crated in the car will be key for her. 

We worked Charlotte on the kennel by doing lots of drills in and out of the kennel. By using the leash to get her in, (it can be messy at first) we can start showing her the crate is actually no big deal. 

After only a few reps Charlotte was willingly going in on her own AND fell asleep shortly afterward i the kennel. 

Dogs often fear things they just don’t know. When you create a positive association to the kennel and just make it a neutral safe space for them, they end up loving it. 

It’s when the crate is used for punishment (which we NEVER recommend doing) that the negative associations are created. 

Most dogs once kennel trained will go into the kennel and lie down without even being told. 

Charlotte is a nervous dog by nature, her owner just adopted her last week and said she was the dog in the corner with a tucked tail and shaking. 

So having a safe place for her to go is super important— especially for our nervous dogs.

Dogs are creatures of their environment. 

Let’s take the standard highly aroused, no manners dog who is friendly as can be, but doesn’t listen and “rules the roost”.

Chances are, this dog would do great with some proper training, structure and leadership. We work with these dogs all the time. 

The thing is- these dogs behave this way because they’re allowed to. It’s as simple as that. 

Dogs are selfish by nature, and they will do things that are self rewarding. Jumping on people, chewing furniture, barking at stuff outside—it’s fun and games. And all easy to stop or change. 

The issue often lies within the dog/human relationship. The owners might feel “bad” for disciplining their dogs, or have been told every lie in the book about how wrong it is to do so. So instead they all struggle for possibly the lifetime of the dog. 

Humans are also creatures of habits, and if our own habits are encouraging bad behaviors, then it becomes a vicious cycle. 

The dog misbehaves, the owner feels bad, the owner gives MORE freedom, more exercise, more fun, more love because that’s what they’re told to do. Instead of just enforcing rules and correcting all the nonsense, the dog just does it more. 

The cycle of self rewarding behavior continues until a breaking point is typically reached. 

Then the owners might seek help, and the right trainer can get results that seem like “magic” when all we do is use an approach that makes sense to the dog. 

We are fair, clear and consistent with our messaging. We don’t allow bad behaviors, we stop them. We reward what we want. OUR attitude and relationship with the dog is built on mutual respect, not one sided as many dog/owner relationships are. 

We get the results we do because we, the humans, know that our behavior contributes to the dog’s long-term success. 

We educate our clients on these concepts and then eventually, they’re successful too 

The changes in your dog always always always begin with YOU.

We stress public access work so much with our training program because this is the work that allows dogs to go practically everywhere with their owners. 

folks who hire us dont hire us just to have a well behaved dog inside their house.  They hire us to have a well behaved dog everywhere. 

And the only way to get that, is to train EVERYWHERE. You need to constantly be increasing your dog’s threshold for stress and environmentals. Without that skill set, your dogs world will be pretty small. 

I know it may seem like every dog who comes through is just “naturally good” around the situations we put them in, but they don’t just show up that way. 

We give every dog an incredibly strong baseline training before they step foot into a store. That way, at this point the dogs know what we expect of them, and then it’s just holding them accountable from there. 

Sometimes the beginning can be a bit messy, the dogs make mistakes. Of course. They aren’t robots nor do we expect them to be. But we also can’t avoid the work that needs to be done either. 

So we practice every day. The dogs get better every day. It’s a skill set that requires consistent work— just like anything new you’ve ever tried. Your dog needs to be put into situations where they can learn and grow. 

Public access training is such a key part of our program because that’s where a lot of their confidence comes from. Just being in the world and existing around it all.

It is a common problem in our world where dogs will bite and nip people that come into the house, most folks can rationally explain that as “my dogs are being protective, our response is, your dog is protecting you from someone safe, I understand that the dog might think its a stranger, but most people are not letting strangers into your house, and frankly your dog should not be biting people you let into your house.

When someone that leaves the house, that has been there for a while or even a short time the dog will nip/bite them, that one confuses people as to why, well whatever the why is, lets concentrate on how to stop it, you stop it with a correction, NO then apply it, but even before that, what is. Your dogs state of mind at the moment, most families have dogs states of mind and arousal levels in the home and most places that are so extremely high that learning or for the dog to apply what the dog has learned or you are in the process of learning. 

It is also important that you role play these situations over and over so your dog learns to make the correct choices and you both reward and correct depending on the choice they make, both are important parts of learning.

One more reason why you should learn how to control arousal and have an on/off switch on your dog as well as the importance of teaching your dog what is acceptable and what is not acceptable.

It seems like more than ever we are being asked about nervous/fearful dogs and how to help them. 

More dogs seem to be struggling with this behavior recently, and it could be due to genetics, but also the fact that dogs just aren’t being trained or pushed past their thresholds during the most critical periods of their development. 

Take Coco (the dog in this video) for example. She was 11 months old in the video, so still a young dog, and was experiencing a lot of fear during her first heat. Rather than avoiding all the triggers (the list was endless it would have been impossible) we worked her THROUGH them and showed her how to overcome the fear. 

We do it ideally when the dogs are younger so this behavior doesn’t become instilled in them, but sometimes you just have no choice. If you adopt a dog later in life etc. 

But we train them all similarly. We don’t avoid triggers. We help the dog get over them by giving guidance and exposure. 

You see how quickly coco gets over this hang up (20 seconds maybe?) or we could have spent weeks desensitizing her or asking her to do this task one step at a time? 

Instead, we just show her how simple it can really be and she learned how to do it on her own without any guidance from us. 

This is how you build a more confident dog for the long term. Not by coddling them and avoiding every single thing they are nervous about. 

Lead them with confidence and structure, and show them what you want. Be consistent. Don’t give up at the first sign of pushback.

As dog owners, and trainers, we are faced daily with thousands of thoughts about the dogs we are living or working with. 

So many people get stuck in the “right” vs “wrong” mindset. It IS or it ISN’T. 

The thing is, there’s really isn’t ONE right way to train a dog out there…Just lots of people arguing over whose methods work best or what you definitely shouldn’t do when it comes to training a dog. 

So what do you do? 

We like to keep things super simple. 

Do you want more of what already is, or less?

I ask myself these simple questions whenever working with a dog, I encourage my clients to do the same, and it has never steered me wrong. 

Is this way of thinking or method helping the dog’s behavior or hurting it? 

Is this moment in time creating progress or chaos? 

Are the emotions of the human actually hindering the training? 

That’s really it. A few simple questions to ask yourself each day as you progress along your training journey. 

It’s a lot more simple than you think. 

Don’t get caught up in analysis paralysis. 

Doing What’s best for the dog isn’t always necessarily what’s best for your human emotions and needs. We have found that’s where the biggest hang ups tend to be. 

We are in the process of launching a brand new course right now on how we rehab fearful dogs. This behavior is often harder to work with than aggression. Simply because human emotions almost always play a major role in the outcome. 

We specialize in behavioral cases like this and thought it was time to teach everything we know in video format.

So many folks struggle with the walk, leash reactivity, pulling, constant sniffing and marking, leash reactivity, aggression, redirecting and so much more.
One of the things you can do is get the dog in the correct state of mind prior to the walk, its sounds counter productive as of course you want your dog to enjoy the walk, but you as the human also want to enjoy the walk, I have never seen a dog that we have had to give a proper correction prior to the walk to get the dog into the correct state of mind not enjoy the walk.

Then once on the walk, you can communicate with your dog at much lower intensity, be more proactive and way less corrective, and you can start being more proactive teaching what you expect…its actually quite exciting and then you both have a great walk, leash reactivity and a dog pulling is no fun for anyone.

Vader is on day 8 of training with us, and we have already been able to get him out to the cafe and Home Depot. 

His owner put a good foundation on him already which has helped a ton, but now we just need to solidify it all and really start to give him the exposure he needs. 

A week ago, Vader would have practically yanked your arm off to flee from strangers and any stressful situations. 

We are teaching him how to actually control his impulses and remain calm. By advocating for him and not allowing people to pet him or force their way into his space, we are teaching Vader that he can trust us, and that nothing bad will happen. 

We have to get him past his current stress thresholds though, otherwise we will just be re-living the same training sessions day after day. 

Instead, we work to push him a little further with every session, so that he can learn what he is actually capable of. 

Most dogs DONT actually know how to handle stress. That’s why you need to teach them. Because the real world is full of unpredictability, and you can’t plan for everything. 

By getting Vader out and about, outside of his comfort zone, we are seeing him slowly but surely come out of his shell. 

It’s going to be a long process for his owner to continue even after training, but we are giving him a great head start. 

We are documenting the entire process for our fearful dog course, and this course applies not only to fearful dogs, but ANY insecure or unmotivated dog.

Vader the cane corso and Wes the GSD are both intact males. When we first integrated Vader into the pack, we took safety protocols of course. He’s never met our dogs and we don’t expect them to be best friends, but we do want them to be able to walk together. Vader is a very insecure dog, so he actually benefits from the confidence of our personal dogs. 

At first, we start out with the intact two on opposite sides. 

Once that goes well enough, we had Wes switch to the left but kept Tex (the neutered mal) as a buffer. 

We would have left it this way, but Vader actually chose to come to the inside of the pack vS the outside (he’s insecure remember) and Wes took the middle. 

They both willingly chose these positions, so we just let it happen. We would never force them to walk beside eachother- especially if they were giving obvious cues that they were uncomfortable, but we just weren’t getting those vibes at all. 

When walking a pack of dogs it’s important to pay attention to their body language and allow them to walk where THEY feel most comfortable. 

Now If they chose to walk near eachother but we saw some sketchiness, posturing etc happening of course then we would absolutely make them walk in different positions. 

Always pay close attention to your dogs and what they’re telling you. That’s how fights and pack attacks are prevented.

Vader the cane corso is with us for some pretty intense fear rehab. 

He’s basically afraid of the outside world, and we have our work cut out for us with this guy. He has a strong flight response to stimuli, so we turn every interaction with him into a training opportunity. 

His walks are not just for walking/exercise. 

We use the walk to get a ton of training drills in along the way. So we don’t focus on distance necessarily, but the quality of the session is what matters. 

During this 20 minute walk, we were able to proof his heel, downstays with distractions, give him exposure to his triggers, and also address his state of mind. 

Remember when you’re working with a Fearful dog, or Any dog for the matter, you are technically training them 24/7. 

Don’t just save your training for your 30 minutes to an hour a day you’re actively working on it. 

Train like it’s a lifestyle, because it is

You can get so many reps in during a walk, and your dog will actually be more mentally stimulated with a training walk than an exercise walk for distance. 

Vader is improving every day that he’s with us, and it’s been great to see him grow more confident through training. (This video was taken about a week ago, so he’s come a long way since then)

Can your dog hold command around distractions?

Will they break place for an open door, food, or a toy?

Why does any of this matter?

It matters because if your dog can’t hold command around small distractions like that inside of your house, your dog definitely won’t be able to hold commands or listen to you in the real world where it matters most. 

Although sweet pea is with us for his behavioral issues with other dogs, we start out ALL dogs training this way. 

It’s slow and steady, and we gradually increase distractions etc so that we can teach the dogs what we want as well as what we don’t. 

It’s important they understand that obedience is nonnegotiable no matter what is happening around them. 

The more impulse control you can instill, the more reliable of a dog you’ll have. 

This all indirectly carries over to his behavior with the other dogs as well. 

If we can help SweetPea think about his decisions before acting on sheer impulse, then we will have a self aware dog that understands all actions have consequences, both positive and negative.

Our 4 pack from California is learning the “out” command. 

It’s SUCH an important command for every dog to know. Eventually this will be applicable to more than the food bowl. 

It will be applied to get the dogs to move away from eachother and humans. 

These 4 dogs have a history of guarding humans from eachother and also getting into scuffles 

Firm boundaries and non negotiable obedience will bring a lot of structure and order to the pack, which will eventually eliminate a lot of the nonsense that’s been going on back home. 

To start your out command, do the following:
1. Find something the dog is interested in, a toy, food, or even a persons affection

2. Have a leash on the dog, and allow the dog to eat, play, etc with the high value item 

3. Say the word “out” then give a leash pop and get the dog away from the item. 

4. Say “break!” And allow the dog to go back to the item 

5. Repeat this over and over a few times a day until the dog starts “outing” on verbal cues and doesn’t rely on leash guidance any longer 

This can eventually be transferred to the remote collar for off leash reliability as well. 

We have so many videos on YouTube showing this, and if you have a truly dangerous dog, we have an entire course on how we stop resource guarding!

What does having a trained dog look like to you? 

A dog that does commands for treats here and there, or a dog that is 100% reliable with ALL obedience inside and outside of your home? 

We consider the latter a trained dog, and that is the standard we train every client dog up to. 

Sweet pea here came to us OUT of control if you remember his intake. He was lunging at other dogs, attacking his housemates, shaking with anxiety, and couldn’t follow a command without food in hand. 

It’s been a little over 2 weeks and we are seeing a totally different dog (in the best way possible) and Courtney is not doing any “magic” with him. 

She has taught him a baseline of obedience, and now it’s time to take it out into the real world to proof it over and over again. 

That’s how you get a reliable dog. 

That’s how you pattern behaviors. 

That’s how you make training a lifestyle. 

Make it so it feels like habit to both you and your dog, and you’ll be surprised how quickly things change and build upon each other.

Whenever we talk about obedience, people are typically surprised we don’t teach “stay”. That’s because our “stay” is built right into the commands. 

Down = down until you’re released and I say “break”
Place, sit, heel, and recall all follow this same rule. 

All commands come with an implied “stay” 

So how do you get the dog out of command? Use a release cue like “break” or “free”
 
Then your dog will have a clear distinction between when they’re in command or not. No more blurred lines. 

When a dog is on break, they’re technically free to do whatever they want. Run, sniff, play, or in most dogs cases: follow their handler and remain engaged with them. 

In this video, Courtney is not requiring any of the dogs to stay with her. But trained dogs historically just do. 

Why? Because when you’ve spent hours and weeks and months training a dog, building a relationship, and basically becoming that dogs entire world…. Why would they ever want to leave your side? 

That’s the beauty of a trained dog 😎

Do you have an overly needy dog who’s always in your space and begging for attention? 

Cute at first, but eventually can become a pretty annoying behavior especially if you have young kids and/or newborn children in the home. 

If you’re carrying a baby, a toddler, or even just enjoying your morning coffee, you should be able to do so in peace without the dog pawing at your or bumping into you for affection. 

We love our “out” command for this reason because it’s so versatile. We can use it to have dogs move away from a certain space, to drop things from their mouth, and to get dogs to move away from eachother. 

In this video, you see how trainer Courtney transitioned away from a verbal out to an automatic one, to make life even easier for Sweetpea’s owners. 

He’s understanding now that when his petting time is over, he needs to break off and go find something else to do. It’s automatic, whereas before the training he would have just pushed harder for MORE attention. 

It’s boundaries like these that help create well rounded family dogs. 

The small stuff IS the big stuff, and it all gets addressed for the most holistic approach to training.

The big mistake a lot of dog owners are making is they jump from training program to training program thinking they MUST be missing something or that they’re just not working hard enough. Why are their dogs STILL not behaving??

The only difference between one well trained dog, or two, or even five…is a well planned routine that works for you no matter where you are, and what your dog is struggling with. 

You don’t need to exhaust your dogs or add another 3 miles to your daily walks to get better behavior (maybe you can’t even imagine taking a walk right now due to your dogs’ nonsense!)

And you definitely don’t need to be frustrated or confused any longer. 

Here’s exactly what we want you to do if you’re ready to start seeing consistently good behavior from your dogs…

1. Train a STRONG obedience foundation
2. Proof that foundation around any and all distractions, including your other dogs. 
3. Add a massive amount of structure to your dogs’ daily life

Those 3 things are the basis of creating peace and harmony within your home.

You’ll often hear out there that ANY sort of correction or aversive toward your dog will completely ruin your relationship. Your dog will lose trust in you, be afraid of you, the list goes on. 

Weirdly enough we have never seen this happen, and that’s after rehabbing thousands of dogs all over the world. We only see the bond and the relationship get BETTER from giving dogs clarity. 

Now, if the only thing we did was correct dogs then sure, they’d probably be afraid of us. But are doing way more than that. 

We are living and training with these dogs 24/7. We are showing them both sides of the coin. We are using positive reinforcement 99% of the time to pattern the behaviors we do want. We are doing activities with the dogs. We are living and bonding with them. 

We aren’t just correcting them until they do what we want. That aurally makes zero sense. You can’t correct a dog for somethjng it doesnt know. No correction will put a new behavior into a dogs head. *insert common sense here* 

So if you’re struggling with any sort of behavioral issues with your dog, and you’re wondering if stopping these behaviors will hinder your relationship, let this post be the confirmation that it will NOT! 

Teach your dog what you want and what you don’t want. It’s only fair!

If your dog is struggling with arousal before the walk, don’t just rush into the walk. 

This video was taken last week from when spooky first got dropped off, and his adrenaline was through the roof. 

He was constantly on alert and gunning for that front door when we knew it was time to go outside. 

One simple protocol you can do is use your body to claim space around the door or any area of the house that the dog is hyper aroused around. 

Notice how much space he ends up creating between himself and the door before we proceed outside. 

And then instead of a walk, we spend some time practicing duration commands and demanding more calmness from him. 

Anxiety, pushiness, and rude behavior do not get him where he wants to go. 

 We proceed with the walk when his state of mind is in check. Sometimes this process will go on for a few days or even the first week, we are in no rush to go around the block. 

You can’t rush the foundation work, otherwise you’ll be chasing behaviors forever.

Working your dog through fears doesn’t need to be this huge ordeal. We do it every day and people are often surprised how simple it can be. 

I think many dog owners are building up this earth shattering event in their mind when it comes time to actually “do the thing” their dog is afraid of, and their own mental fears hold them back more than anything. 

If we stopped the training session every time spooky got “spooked” we’d never make it around the block.

Instead, we just work him through the issue over and over until he realizes he can just do it. We follow this formula for every dog we train, and we’ve never seen it not work. 

This took all of 10 minutes at most for this particular issue, and we just held him accountable for his heel and corrected the flighty behavior. 

Your dog is way smarter and way more capable of handling stress than you’ve been told. 

Pushing them past their current thresholds is all part of training and building a bombproof dog. Spooky will have more confidence after this session and now knows what the level of expectation is on the walk now, and always, moving forward.

When I think about the success rate our training programs have at Solid K9, it all can pretty much be traced back to 5 basic concepts that we implement every day. 

1. We always start with foundation work no matter WHAT a dog is struggling with. Aggression? Anxiety? Fear? Doesn’t matter. All dogs need a rock solid baseline of training. Otherwise we’d just be spinning our wheels trying to put out fires. 

2. We keep it simple. We aren’t training pet dogs to be competitors and we know the limitations of the dogs we work with. We aren’t asking them to do anything unreasonable. 

3. We are consistent AF! We do not change our tune with dogs and we are always fair and consistent. No mixed messages. Ever. 

4. We train dogs both sides of the coin— both what we want and we make it clear what we DONT want. It’s not fair to them otherwise. 

5. We transfer all training to whatever tools communicate and work best for the dogs + humans. (Typically a remote collar) This not only gives the dogs a better quality of life, but it does so for their owners too. We spend A LOT of time training the humans. This is THE most important concept in everything we do. Without educated and empowered owners, we wouldn’t have trained dogs outside of our environment. The training NEEDS to transfer. (Another reason why we love training tools so much) 

These things are the reason why our training programs just work so well. We have a high success rate because we choose to continue building our craft and Helping as many people and dogs as we possibly can. 

That’s why we are launching the Green to Graduate II program beginning June 10th! 

This is a LIVE event that’s nothing like we’ve ever done before. 

You’ll learn our entire training program from start to finish + see first hand how we are able to get the results that we do.

After meal time can be a prime time for dogs to fight especially if they’re not eating in their kennels. 

(Which is why we ALWAYS recommend feeding in crates) 

But as you can see the dogs are scavenging around, nosing through other dogs bowls, even sniffing the trash to see what else they can find. All big “no-no’s” in our book. 

To stop this behavior we typically will correct the dogs with a “no” or “enough” and then send them to place to relax for a while. 

Dogs will guard a lot of random stuff in the house, including empty bowls and even the areas where they typically eat. 

You need to have firm boundaries around meal times to not only show the dogs you are the one in charge of all food, but also to avoid any major discrepancies from happening. 

As much as we all want a multi dog household to be seamless and effortless, we need to be realistic. It’s always going to require some management and structure. 

A free for all lifestyle with any dog, human, or child just isn’t realistic. 

Don’t be afraid to enforce rules to keep the peace. 

We will be covering all household management protocols and more in our most interactive LIVE course to date: green to graduate 2!!!

I don’t train my relatives dogs, neighbors dogs, friends dogs etc…just a policy I have, but my folks have owned this dog for 12 years, the dog is highly reactive and pulls like crazy and when it sees a dog goes nuts, they walk the dog on a harness, that’s fine, their choice and I respect it as they are not my clients and don’t ask for help. After todays post about the pulling frenchie and the dog returned to the shelter. This is not a conversation about tools at all, so the dog was pulling and being reactive on tonights walk.

So for the first time ever I asked my mom for the leash, did about 15 seconds of teaching and then calmly walked their dog around the block past dogs that it usually explodes on, and the dogs where exploding on their dog as I was walking , did it  all on a harness, not a no pull harness but a harness that actually encourages pulling. So a competent dog trainer can either train a dog to walk nicely on a leash or not, its not about prong collars or e-collars, its about skill set, and if you are a dog trainer you can do this in a few minutes or even a few seconds or you can’t. It’s the most basic concept there is.

Another example of how harnesses don’t give you any leverage on a walk, especially with a large breed dog. 

Hugo is with us for resource guarding and lack of obedience skills in general. So what do we mean by that? 

Obedience to us, even as a baseline level, means a dog that can do the following: 

👉walk nicely on a leash anywhere 
👉follow commands reliably around any and all distractions 
👉hold commands for extended periods of time (we’re talking hours not minutes) 
👉can relax + be calm when told to do so
👉can be trusted both on + off leash around high levels of distractions 

As you can see, in his very first walk we were able to completely stop the pulling behavior + get Hugo into a “follower” state of mind. 

This will allow us to now train him everything else without a ton of conflict because he’s actually willing to learn and participate. 

Trying to train an out of control overly aroused dog is pretty much a waste of time. They’re not receptive to listening or absorbing anything you teach them. 

Work on the state of mind first, and then youll have a much more receptive dog.

It’s time to toss all those negative beliefs about your dog out the window

Your dog *IS* trainable, your current methods just aren’t working

No dog that we’ve ever worked with has been “untrainable”

Unmotivated with well established bad behaviors? Sure. But definitely still trainable. 

Most the the dogs we have trained were at one point labeled “hard headed”, “stubborn”, “defiant.” But all we’re seeing are dogs who lack a clear communication system that actually WORKS for them.

Putting labels on your dog only creates more of a story to hold onto, and those stories keep you stuck.

What about instead of calling your dog “untrainable” you said “my dog just lacks clarity on his/her expectations.”

Because that’s really all dog training boils down to. Does your dog understand the expectations, have you taught those expectations, and are you consistent with those expectations?

Any successful training program should (at a minimum) include the following:
-a reward based system to create positive associations with your commands
-a consistent marker system 
-a clear communication system
-corrections for unwanted behavior/non compliance of known commands 

Once you have this recipe to follow, the rest becomes SO much easier on you and the dog.

It’s through this very simple system that we are able to fully off leash train dogs and create SOLID reliability in their training. 

It’s how we have helped so many people all over the world. We keep it simple! 

So if you’ve been wanting to learn our EXACT processes on how we sucessfully train dogs, then you’re in luck.

The doors to our first ever LIVE Green to Graduate 2 workshop are OPEN!

No more second guessing yourself, or wondering why your dog is “untrainable.”

When you join me in this workshop, we will spell it all out for you & get you on the fast track to a RELIABLY trained dog.

Don’t take this the wrong way, but most dog owners do not need any help giving their dogs MORE affection and love. 

Most dog owners come to us with out of control dogs who are creating mayhem in their lives. 

Too much freedom, lack of boundaries, affection at the wrong times, these are all the recipe for an entitled, pushy dog. 

And this typically manifests with aggression or other unwanted behaviors. 

The first thing we talk about with our clients is “what’s the rest of the day look like?”

Are you holding your dog accountable? Enforcing rules? Correcting for non compliance or bad behavior in general? 

When the balance is off, so is the behavior and the relationship historically. 

Our clients love their dogs, of course!!! But dogs need more than love when it comes to living a balanced life within your home.

It’s always funny to me when people jump on our page and claim that ALL training tools are “shutting dogs down” and “inflicting pain and misery” onto them.

When you actually look at the dogs we train and rehabilitate, you see that they are actually 10x happier than they were when they initially came to us.

Every dog that we’ve ever trained with any kind of tool ends up as a better version of themselves.

These dogs understand what true freedom feels like. 

These dogs learn that the world is much, much larger than the 4 walls of their home. 

These dogs learn that training = going places with your owner and being highly involved in their every day life. 

We have never seen dogs ruined from e collar or prong collar training. That’s just something you hear about on the internet from the folks who have never actually tried them.

The truth is, the dog owners who are invested enough to learn how to use these tools, are the dog owners who are also terrified of “messing up their dogs.”

They’re educating themselves, using the tools as they were intended to be used, and they’re always learning about how to make themselves and their dogs better.

Different rules for different dogs? 

But is it FAIR? 

We get asked this question all the time and the answer is 100% yes. It’s fair and it should be a non-issue within the home. 

We are firm believers that a dog’s behavior dictates the amount of freedom they are allowed, especially in the beginning stages of training. 

Hugo struggles with resource guarding and other behavioral issues while his housemate does not. 

So Hugo will be held more accountable to keep the leadership and belief system strong when he gets back home. Meanwhile his housemate will just be living life as usual. And that’s ok!!! 

Dogs don’t look at things like humans do, nor do they think that deeply into it. 

many owners, and even we ourselves, have different rules for each dog based on their behaviors. 

That’s just the way it is. And that’s why we always say “train the dog in front of you”. 

Rules & freedom will always apply to each dog individually

Hubble learned to swim this week as his owners have a pool at home they want him to use. 

At first of course it’s stressful for the dog as they get used to it and learn to use their back legs to keep them level, but after a few reps you can see he gets better each time. 

At a minimum, every dog that lives in a home with a pool should know how to get OUT of the pool just in case they ever fell in. It’s a big safety protocol for us as well as a confidence booster!

Hubble just had his mid training and we decided to do it at his owners home since they are local to us. 

One of his biggest issues was barking and jumping on people when they entered the home, so we made sure that this behavior was completely under control even in an environment where it’s well practiced. 

We role play whatever the dog struggles with over and over so that they learn to make better decisions. 

Don’t wait until you’re in the heat of the moment to start proofing! Set it up so you can show your dog what success feels like!

Teaching a dog to swim can sometimes be a messy process, but it something that we find extremely important especially in households with a pool. 

You’d be surprised how many dogs actually drown in pools every year. 

We teach this life saving skill because the obvious, it can save their life, but also, they usually end up LOVING it! 

But getting them over the initial hesitation can be a bumpy ride. 

We just use some leash pressure to get the dog in, and then we also use the leash to direct them and lead them back to the stairs. 

Dogs need to know how to EXIT the pool as well (for safety) 

Once they learn to use their back legs, they start rocking and rolling and it’s a very enjoyable experience for the dogs. 

Share this with someone who might need to hear it!

Whenever you see well behaved dogs out in public, just know the owners with those dogs are busting their asses for that success and doing the work it takes. 

No, it’s not luck. 

No, the dog wasn’t just “born that way” 

The truth is, most dogs come into our worlds not knowing what to do, what the expectations are, and they definitely don’t communicate the way we do. 

So how can we as dog owners just sit back and assume our dogs know how to behave in a human world? 

That’s not fair. And waiting it out to see if the dog grows out of the behavior is only allowing them time to grow INTO it. 

Training is key. 

It’s not a last resort. 

It’s not something you do if you have some extra time. 

Training and dog ownership go hand in hand. 

If you’re going to sign up for the 15-20 year commitment of owning a dog, training should be at the top of the priority list just like vet care. 

So next time you see a well behaved dog out in public, just know that dog wasn’t born that way! And the human at the other end of the leash has been doing their thousands of reps, proofing, and everything else it takes to have a reliable dog 👏🏻

A better walk means you need to start enforcing better behavior INSIDE the home, too. 

It’s never just a bandaid approach when it comes to dogs. 

If your dog is slipping on the walk and acting poorly, chances are there are some things going on in the home that have an effect on the walk, too. 

Check your dogs behavior from minute you decide it’s time for a walk. From their energy at the crate door, to the front door, to when you put the leash and collar on, it ALL matters. 

Don’t let those little moments pass by because “it’s not a big deal.” Because when you start cleaning up the tiny messes the big ones tend to disappear, too. 

We often talk about how the dogs overall behavior is connected to the walk, as it’s such an overlooked solution.

Start holding your dog accountable for everything, raise the bar and your expectations, and see how fast your walk changes (for the better)

Winston is with us for his separation anxiety and what’s the beginning stages of resource guarding his owner 

He’s always glued to his owner and it’s creating some issues for them both. 

Winston needs to learn how to be calm and collected on his own, since his owner can’t realistically be with him 24/7. 

Good crate manners are where we start with every dog. 

Calmness in the kennel will carry over to calmness outside of it, and eventually it’ll become a patterned behavior for Winston while he’s just hanging in the house. 

We teach this concept starting day one with asking the dog to “down” in the kennel, and then we make that the new baseline. 

A dog who is lying down calmly in a kennel is a dog who will likely just fall asleep and relax (see end of video) 

But if you allow a dog to pace, spin, pant, whine, they will only escalate that behavior to worse behavior. 

Kennel manners are a must in our training program because we know it has such an impact on a dog’s overall behavior.

Working a dog through stress is a necessary part of training. 

The world is not a staged and set-up bubble that will keep your dog under threshold at all times. 

If you truly want a dog that can go places with you and not fall apart at the slightest of distractions, then it’s imperative you work on their stress thresholds and allow them to make mistakes & troubleshoot. 

This is where the real work comes into play, and where we see the most progress happen.

When it comes to dog ownership, many of us are guilty of putting our human emotions/needs on the dog instead of seeing things for what they are: a dogs needs are NOT the same as ours. 

Do dogs need food, water and shelter? That’s a given. 

But I’m talking about the deeper rooted stuff. 

The humanization of dogs and their emotions. 

If you’re afraid of correcting certain behaviors or instilling certain rules when it comes to the dog because you might “hurt their feelings” I hate to tell you that you will likely struggle when it comes to any behavioral issues down the road. 

Dogs don’t rationalize the way we do. 

Dogs learn in the moment, yes or no, matter of fact. They have NO idea what our words mean without having some action to back them up. 

Every day we get emails from folks who say “I tell my dog NO but it keeps repeating [insert behavior here]”

Have you truly given “no” any value?

Have you given any of your words value? 

That’s where training comes into play, and it’s often the hardest component for us because it involves human emotion. 

In reality—rules, structure and boundaries are the clearest and most kind thing you could do for you dog. But all too often our own rationale is what holds us and the dogs back.

Ever been told “correcting your dog for [insert bad behavior here] will create a negative association to it”?

Well, you’ve been lied to. 

Never, ever, have we seen dogs become superstitious of the things they once reacted to…

Think about it— the dog is ALREADY reacting to other dogs, lunging at people, freaking out in the crate, charging the front door. How could you possibly make the association any worse by correcting it? The association is already terrible without you trying to stop it. 

We only see dogs get over the issue with a well timed and proper correction, and then we can begin patterning long-term behaviors that we do want. 

That fear mongering is only keeping people stuck, and it really doesn’t need to be so complicated to stop unwanted behavior in your dog.

We always control the energy of dogs before we socialize. It’s dangerous to assume random dogs can just get together and have no issues. You might own “that dog” but the truth of the matter is, most dogs don’t get along with strange dogs, especially rude ones. That’s why we have such controlled social environments to create the safest situation for all dogs involved.
Angelo and I after climbing to the  cave of Zeus. So much great history on this Island and Angelo being a HUGE Mythology buff is loving it

Most dogs don’t want to be friends with every dog they meet. That’s why we focus so heavily on existence before acceptance. 

We really don’t care if dogs have a bunch of playmates, but we do want dogs to be able to just chill while there’s other dogs around. 

Why? Because if your dog can ignore other dogs, your world together will be a lot bigger. 

You cannot and should not expect your dog to just LOVE every dog they come into contact with. This will only create unrealistic expectations and a lot of undesirable behaviors like reactivity and or aggression. 

If you must have two dogs from different households meet, always start with calmly existing together first, or a walk without them actually greeting. 

Sharpei Great Dane dog training dog trainer dog behavior behaviorist collar harness dogs pet dog training tips local puppies social behavior
It’s the dog who ultimately loses when people are afraid to speak up.

Can your dog be around your friends/family’s dogs? 

It depends. 

If the other dogs are untrained, rude, and don’t listen to any obedience commands, it’s going to get messy really quick. 

On the flip side, if the other dogs are capable of ignoring your dog or just hanging out calmly like you see here in the video, it shouldn’t be an issue. 

We train dogs to a level where they can ignore pretty much anything going on, but you have to draw a line somewhere. 

If your dog is behaving and holding command and a random dog is pestering them, stepping on them, or just invading their space constantly, it’s really not fair at all to ask your dog not to respond to something like that. 

That’s where human management comes in, and it’s up to YOU to create boundaries and advocate for your dog. 

Otherwise. Your dog will probably work it out in the way many dogs do—with their teeth. 

And nobody wants that. 

TLDR: don’t bring your dog around other 
dogs unless the other dogs are under control!!

We get asked this question a LOT

“How do I introduce my friendly dog to other dogs?”

But it’s basically an impossible question to answer without being there in person and doing it ourselves. 

Even the friendliest dogs, like the one in this video, can quickly turn a situation sideways 🛑

The friendly dog comes on so strong, it triggered the other dog into defense which then turned into an all out pack fight. ‼️

Even the best of intentions can come across wrong to some dogs. 

Some dogs don’t know how to give a proper correction. I actually own a dog like this. He doesn’t just correct dogs for acting inappropriately, he will full out brawl. There is no in between for him. That’s why it takes a special skill set to handle him and socialize him, I do not EVER let him interact with unknown dogs. 

I also own a dog who is super sweet and can be very neutral around pretty much any dog, however, if a dog snaps at him or comes after him, he’s not going to just back down, he will defend himself for sure. 

I’ve also owned dogs who run away from conflict at all cost and want NOTHING to do with it. 

But just like humans, dogs are individuals and you don’t know how a strange dog will trigger them to react. ❓

That why we are huge advocates of only having neutral greetings at first and never ever letting dogs just rush up to each other like you see in the video. 

Obviously shit happens sometimes, and these women handled the situation very appropriately— hopefully without any injuries. 

Dogs are not meant to be friends with every dog they meet. That’s an unfair expectation to put on them that often leads to reactivity, aggression and/or fearful behavior from negative experiences. 😬

You’ve likely heard the phrase before…

“Calm on command” ❓

many people ask us how we get this state of mind in dogs, and the truth is, it’s not anything “magical” that we do. 🪄 

It all starts by teaching the dog a stationary command like “place” and building in more and more duration over time. ⏰ 

We get the dogs to the point where they can hold the command for extended periods of time, around all kinds of distractions, and then we pattern that behaviors to pretty much any indoor + outdoor scenario that we choose. 👏

Once a dog has enough practice and you’ve been consistent with your follow through, it sort of naturally becomes their default behavior. 💯

Our personal dogs know that inside the house = be calm. Outdoors is for play and excitement. And that’s also why we build in a “release/break” cue to every command. 👏🏻

When the dog hears “break” it means they’re now free to do whatever they want. Go play, go walk around, go sniff etc. 🌲 

But commands are commands are commands. There is no grey area. 🛑

Commands mean you listen and be calm, while break means go have some fun and “be a dog” if that’s what you want your dog to do. 👍🏻

Calmness on command, though, all starts the same way. With a basic “place” or “down”, and then we build upon it from there. ✅

🗣️🗣️ your dog will not grow out of bad behavior!! 

I don’t know who needs to hear this, but dogs only grow into the behaviors that are reinforced. 

If your 16 week old puppy is jumping and biting at you, you can bet they’ll keep doing it even at a year old. Then it’s adult dog teeth snapping at you with an adult dogs size. 

This is just one example of the many behaviors people are being told not to correct, because it’ll “destroy the relationship with the dog”

I’m not sure about you, but if my dog is biting me I think that’s a pretty shitty relationship to have regardless. 

So why not at least try to fix it so you can have a respectful dog who you enjoy being around. 

It’s really not rocket science here. But allowing your dog to practice bad behavior in hopes they’ll eventually stop will not work.

We are typically rehabbing those dogs a couple years down the road because they’ve practiced it so much it’s become a huge problem. 

Like we always say, proactive training will always be better than reactive training.

Set proper rules and boundaries from the start, correct bad behaviors, train what you do want, and you will have an adult dog who doesn’t even try to push the limits because they understand what’s expected. 

It’s easier to stop behaviors in young dogs because there’s less time for them to reinforce them.

When it comes to leash reactivity, one of the most common questions we get is:

“Can I correct my dog for this behavior, even though they’re not necessarily trained on a certain tool yet?”

And that depends on a lot of things 🧐

Does your dog REALLY understand what the expectations are for the walk❓

Have you taught them a rock solid heel❓

Have you done reps of “heel” work, like all other obedience commands, or do you just let them dictate where you walk and when❓

If your dog isn’t trained to walk nicely in heel then no, its not fair to correct them for the reactivity since you have not even started the foundation work that is required to stop this behavior for the long-term. ❌

But if you’ve done your reps, you’ve worked on exposure, your dog has an incredible heel command…(until they see another dog) them YES, a well timed correction is usually the one thing missing to get you past this hurdle. ✅ 

Then that’s where proper training comes into play, because you can’t just correct your dog when they start barking or exploding on the leash. There is actually a very small window of time where it’s ok to correct, and it can sometimes be so subtle a lot of owners miss it. 🧐

We call this the loading stage, and it’s THE prime moment to have a conversation with your dog…if you miss it, it’s likely too late. Your dog will not care. 😱

Leash reactivity is rampant these days, and often times it’s just a few tweaks to the training that owners are missing.

❌You’re letting your dog rush out the front door. This behavior sets the tone that the dog is actually leading the walk, not you. It also reinforces an excited and aroused state of mind. NOT what we want for the walk, especially if your dog has behavioral issues. 

❌You’re allowing your dog to sniff and mark everything. This pretty much waters down your heel command and teaches the dog that there are absolutely no rules for the walk. Every inch of grass, pavement, tree etc is your dog’s to enjoy. Again, not sending the right message when you are trying to instill leadership. We aren’t against dogs going potty or sniffing, but we are against them doing it while they’re in command.

❌You’re allowing your dog to drag you all over the place. This is not only dangerous, but again, it reinforces to the dog that you’re someone who they don’t need to take seriously or listen to at all. If your dog doesn’t care enough about you to walk beside you while on leash, don’t expect them follow through with a lot of what you ask.

We take the walk pretty seriously around here for many reasons. So instead of it being a free for all, make a few tweaks to your routine and watch it make a world of a difference for you. 👏🏻

✅Have your dog wait patiently in a sit or a down at the front door before stepping outside

✅Only allow your dog to sniff or mark while on a break. If they try to do it while in command, you can correct this behavior.

✅Teach your dog a SOLID heel command that has true value. Start in low distraction environments and work your way up to busier parks or stores. A strong heel command will make your walks better, but also your overall relationship with your dog will improve. YOU will become someone who your dog looks to for guidance instead of them viewing you as the doormat.

Whether you’ve been following us for a while, or you’re brand new here, you most likely know by now that we rarely talk about how to “love your dog properly” 

Most dog owners do not need help in that department. ❌

Most dog owners who come to us need help with stopping terrible behaviors their dogs are displaying or training obedience that actually works around real world distractions. 

We are huge advocates of building a relationship with your dog through training. ✅

This doesn’t mean you can’t love your dog! 

But what it means is we want owners to start holding their dogs to higher standards. Demand more from them.  Don’t just hand out affection all day long and ask nothing of them. 

Why on earth would your dog want to stop acting out if you’re rewarding them all day long with zero consequences for the their behavior? Chances are, you’re likely reinforcing the wrong things because you’re giving affection at the wrong time. 

So many dogs come to us aggressive, anxious, out of control, and they’ve had nothing but love and massive amounts of freedom their entire lives.

If love was all it took to rehab dogs, we wouldn’t be here. 🛑

As a dog trainer who is EXTREMELY client-centric, I want you to be as successful as possible. And that often means stepping up and becoming a leader to your dog vs their friend. 

Once your dog is trained, doing great, not displaying bad behaviors and listening to you the first time you ask… then we can start having more conversations about couch time, snuggles etc. 

But until you have really done your work and changed the way your dog looks at you, “how to love my dog more” is typically not a question that even makes the list. 

And this might come off as “harsh” but I’m speaking from 20 years of working with some of the worst behaved dogs out there. Rehabbing man eaters, dog killers and the like. 

At the end of the day, dogs are predators and they need rules within the home. 

Dogs can also be your best friend, but they need a strong leader to show them right from wrong too.

2 simple protocols that will change your walk forever. 

1. Spatial pressure!!! This is a game changer when it comes to getting dogs to stop forging ahead on the heel. Pretend your body is a wall, and push your dog back claiming the space in front of you. Do it a few times and watch how fast your dog learns to follow behind. 

2. 180 pops on the leash. Every time your dog gets ahead of you, plant yourself, pop the leash, and turn the opposite direction. Your dog will want to catch up to you and will eventually become handler aware, so that when you turn, the dog will turn with you instead of trying to jock for position! 

Try these out & let us know if they helped you! ✅

🤣 💀 hear me out!! 

Everyone, and I mean everyone, experiences some set backs in their training at one point or another. 

Dogs are NOT robots, and even the best of the best make mistakes from time to time ❌

All you can do is get back to business and cut yourself (and your dog) some slack.

But it’s definitely worth it once they’re trained up and doing a ton of awesome stuff with you.

5 things I wish more dog owners knew…

1. Typically the things you’re resisting are the things that need to be done. Like getting your dog out of your bed, holding them accountable for bad behaviors, and not giving them free run of the house. 

2. Loving your dog out of bad behavior isn’t possible. Loving your dog into good behavior isn’t possible. Dogs need rules, structure and boundaries just as much as kids do. It’s not fair to withhold certain information from them simply because it feels “good” to you 

3. Dogs are actually way smarter than you think and know how to take advantage of situations. Ever notice your dog behaves a certain way for you, and entirely different for another person? That’s not just a coincidence… 

4. I am a huge advocate of exercise and mental stimulation for dogs. BUT I don’t think exercise solves behavioral issues. “A tired dog is a good dog” is a lie. A tired dog is just tired for now, and will be right back to its nonsense once rested. 

5. Sit, down, come, heel etc are all worthless commands if your dog can’t do them for extended periods of time around high levels of distractions. Just because your dog can do a “down” for 5 seconds in the kitchen, does not mean your dog truly knows the down command. If you want training that fits your lifestyle, you need to make training a part of your lifestyle.

Tools or no tools…

Whatever tool you do decide to train with…

You still need to understand the basic principals of dog training. 

Shaping, teaching, and creating consistent behaviors is not a process you can magically skip because of a collar your dog is wearing. 

And once you do achieve the desired behaviors, training will NOT last without a consistent owner who is willing to put in the work. 

Tools definitely make training more clear depending on what you’re trying to accomplish, but the basic fundamentals are the same no matter what. 

Every dog trainer/owner out there has one thing in common: they either fully believe in their ability to work the dog and commit to it, or they don’t. 

And the dogs will figure it out very quickly. 

No tool in the world is a substitute for a solid relationship with your dog— and that typically is formed THROUGH training.

We can’t even begin to tell you how many people come to us saying:

“My dog asks for belly rubs and then attacks us!!”

That’s because the belly up isn’t always an invitation for affection. 

It’s an appeasement behavior. Meaning the dog is trying it’s best to avoid conflict, but if pushed too much, things could go sideways. 

Cora is with us for six weeks aggression rehab. She is a KNOWN biting dog who is capable of serious harm. 

For us to put that amount of pressure on her right now would be irresponsible and foolish. 

Eventually we will start working her more and more above threshold, but that doesn’t always involve going for physical touch right away, if ever. 

Some dogs simply do not like physical touch, and it’s not fair to push that on them. Trainers and owners need to know what is an acceptable amount of pressure to put on dogs. 

Now, if she wouldn’t allow things such as collaring up or grooming that would be a different story (those things are necessary in a pet dogs life) however, a dog that doesn’t enjoy a ton of physical pressure put on them? It’s reasonable and sometimes that’s just the dog. 

We won’t know for sure til we really get to know her and work with her more. But we are barely a week into training. 

Our rehab program is a process. And it’s not something that can be achieved overnight. 

Cora is learning day by day that certain behaviors like barking, lunging and growling at us are DEFINITELY not acceptable. 

But when she gives us subtle cues like this? We respect the dog and continue the training without creating unnecessary conflict.
