How to set your dog up for success when company comes over the house? 

The place command! 

This command is so important for a dog to know in a pet household. 

It allows the dog to have a job to do, and keeps them out of trouble! 

Once your dog TRULY knows place, you can begin role playing and proofing their obedience around high distractions. 

This will allow them to not only know the RIGHT thing to do, but also practice what to do if they make a mistake. 

Obedience without solid proofing is basically useless. You need to train for the real world. Period. 

Salty used to jump all over people, steal food and just be generally out of control before training. 

Now she’s able to still be a part of everything while remaining calm and relaxed. 

Place is very simple to teach, and we have dozens of videos on it as well as our online courses that teach not only place, but our ENTIRE training program start to finish. 

You can check them out on solidk9academy.com

Most dog owners out there are doing a great job teaching their dogs obedience, but what’s often missing is teaching them what NOT to do— especially around distractions. 

99% of our clients have already put in some work, so it’s not that they are “lazy”. 

They’re just being given the wrong information. 

Being told they can never correct their dogs or their unwanted behaviors. 

Being told it’s a lifetime struggle and to just keep repeating the same shit that doesn’t work. 

Being told that the relationship will be ruined if they tell their dogs “no” 

But none of it’s true. 

It’s fair to correct your dog for unwanted behaviors, especially if it’s for something they definitely know like breaking command around a distraction.

But for other things like counter surfing, charging the front door, jumping on people, you can correct all of that whether the dog knows obedience or not. 

Behavior and obedience are not the same. 

That’s why we differentiate the two.

We get comments often about our videos and how our client dogs look robotic and there’s “no fun” for them. 

Keep in mind, you’re seeing a 30-60 second clip of the dogs day. And not every minute is spent doing fun stuff. 

Dogs in public are expected to behave a certain way, to us, that means minding their own business and ignoring people and dogs alike. 

We don’t want dogs in training to think it’s ok to say hello to everyone or sniff and mark all over the place. 

We hold them to high standards so that when it is time for off leash fun, they respect us enough to listen when that leash is off.

We build strong relationships with dogs by becoming leaders to them. 

Being afraid of making your dog “too robotic” is like saying you don’t want to lift weights because you might turn into a bodybuilder. 🙄 

There’s nothing wrong with having high standards for your dog. 

Their personalities will continue to shine, but they’ll just understand rules and consequences after training.

How to set your dog up for an off property excursion part 1:

If you’re planning on taking your dog out somewhere, start by controlling the energy from the moment you leave your house. 

Address any whining, excitement, pulling on the leash etc INSIDE your house, then down your driveway, and all the way into the car. 

Your dog should be lying down calmly in the car/kennel the entire ride. 

If not, why? 

Your dog should be able to hold a downstay for an extended period of time before they go out in public, which means you should be able to correct them for non-compliance at this point. 

If your dog breaks command, simply tell them no and correct them back into a down. Remote collar is great for hands free control, especially in the car. 

Once your dog understands that the rules apply to everywhere you go, then you can decide if you want them to be excited at the park, lake, hiking trail, or if you’d rather them remain calm for the store like Home Depot or an outdoor cafe. 

Different environments require different energy, but the beginning of the trip always starts the same…with calmness. 

Our green to graduate 2 program covers this process extensively. We show how to bring your dog to a cafe, a store, and how to work through a lot of the initial nervousness/uncertainty many dogs display in these settings. It was all filmed live and unedited, with Q+A included!

You can check it out on solidk9academy.com

Stay tuned for part 2 where we take these two to Home Depot!

Nail trimming and grooming is often a pain point for many dogs and their owners. 

Dogs can become aggressive when having this procedure done, so it’s important you work them through it. 

Most of the time it’s just because the dog has never been conditioned to it before, so they object in every way they know. 

We typically stop the unwanted behaviors (biting, thrashing, growling etc) then work on the counter conditioning process

But we definitely don’t avoid working the dogs through it. 

Do some dogs LOVE getting their nails done? Absolutely not. 

Do you love going to to the dentist and having your teeth scaled? Probably not. 

But it’s a necessary thing in life.

We really just focus on getting dogs to accept grooming/nail trims vs trying to make them LOVE the concept. 

We break down our whole nail trimming/dremel conditioning process in our nail trimming course. 

It’s only $97 and it works for even the hardest dogs out there.

3 principles that will change your view on dog ownership:

1. Dogs aren’t humans in fur coats. They are actually predators that live in your home. Don’t expect them to “behave” like a human, or automatically know right from wrong. They don’t even understand these concepts until they are shown. You need to TEACH your dogs what you want.

2. The more you allow things to slide, the more you pattern those behaviors in the long-run. If your dog is constantly breaking command, barking out the window, tearing up things in the house…don’t think for a second they will just stop until you do something about it. 

3. Your own behavior has more to do with dog training than the dog’s. The way your dog perceives you (are you believable or not?) will dictate how they act in your presence. No amount of dog training is a substitute for a weak relationship.

if you are constantly struggling with your dog’s behavior, it might be because you’re just following the wrong training program, and not getting enough training YOURSELF. 

The dog is only half of the equation. 

We find the most successful dog owners are the one’s who are willing to step up and get out of their comfort zones to show up as the leader their dogs need them to be.

Do we set dogs up to fail? Of course we do, the great thing is we set dogs up and train dogs to succeed thousands of times with all of their commands and behaviors, but if you truly want to stop an unwanted or dangerous behavior, you need to set up a dog to fail so you can correct the dog and teach the dog that certain behaviors are not allowed. I am puzzled why someone would not want to teach their dog what is acceptable and what is not acceptable.

I find it interesting that when we talk about this folks assume that is all we do is correct our dogs for doing things the wrong things, anyone that has seen us train, watched any of our FULL training videos, watched any of our live videos where nothing is edited, they would see that we want dogs to succeed so much so we don’t have to correct them. 

For folks to think that anyone can go through life without learning what is wrong is just not thinking on a rational and realistic real world level. It will save your dogs life by teaching a dog what is right and what is wrong. So instead of waiting to do something wrong, you do the same concepts of teaching someone what is right. You actually teach them, you role play, you test them, you practice, you give input, you make adjustments. When they then do it correct, you give them positive feedback.

It’s the same with teaching them what not to do, teach them, you follow through, you make sure they understand that it is not acceptable, you make sure they understand. Then your dog knows what is acceptable and what is not acceptable. I can’t imagine a world where living beings do not learn what is acceptable and what is not acceptable, this will lead to the possible death of a dog, lots of stress for the owner, financial consequences to the owner and not a full life for the dog or the owner.

We get emails, comments and DM’s every day about dogs who are becoming destructive, aggressive, guarding space in the home, etc. 

And it all boils down to this: your dog has TOO much freedom that they haven’t earned the right to have yet. 

Yep, we said it. Your dog should earn its freedom within the home.

And we don’t mean have your dog locked up 24/7, but just instilling the smallest amount of leadership will make all the difference. 

Utilize a crate when you can’t directly supervise, put a leash on INSIDE the house, and be consistent with your own behavior as well as the dogs. 

These simple changes will make ALL the difference in your life and the dogs. 

If you need help with how to crate train, structure your day, or even train reliable obedience, our Green to Graduate 2 program covers all of this and more. It’s our most complete program for training a reliable family dog.

Even the friendliest dogs with the best of intentions can lead OTHER dogs to snapping and or over-correcting. Which can then lead to dog fights. 

In this video, you see the Frenchie (who is super sweet and sociable) rush up to the schnauzers guns blazing. She’s all up in their business (we let her be) but we knew it was likely only a matter of time before one of the dogs told her to F off. 

Knowing these two aren’t dangerous dogs, we assumed it would play out exactly as it did, with Theo giving her a good correction for being so pushy. 

Smurf learned her lesson and was quite respectful afterward. 

Theo and Beau both came to us highly dog reactive, BUT this does NOT mean they are dog aggressive!! 

A dog can be explosive on the leash but get along with dogs just fine. 

Theo’s reaction to Smurf was not over the top, as you can tell by his body language he was trying to tell her to back off subtly before he corrected her. 

WE actually should be the ones correcting Smurf for being so crazy, so she can learn to read social cues better. (We let it play out because we had a good feeling Theo would react appropriately, but if your dog is known to snap and over correct, then it’s best YOU intervene before that happens)

Some dogs just don’t know, and their energy often gets them into trouble although they don’t mean for it to.

That’s why understanding your dogs body language is so important and advocating for your dogs in social settings is even MORE important. 

You need a healthy balance when dealing with multiple dogs.

Ares is with us for her fearfulness around men. 

And when it comes to working with skittish dogs, we never avoid triggers. We face them head on. 

We first address the outward displays of unwanted behavior like barking or lunging. 

Then step two is advocating for the dog, making sure they understand WE have things under control, and then lastly becomes existence and/or acceptance.

We aren’t really concerned about Ares LOVING strangers. But we do need her to be able to exist around them without causing a scene. 

This is just day one of her training, and we have a long way to go over the next six weeks, but that’s how quickly you can stop behavior like this. 

It doesn’t need to take months and you don’t need to try and make everything a wonderful experience. 

Show your dog that they ARE capable, show them you’re in control, and they will eventually start learning that there’s no need to react at all.

Imagine this: 

It’s a crisp fall morning 🍁 You’re sipping your coffee, eating a pastry, catching up on emails, and your dog is lying quietly by your side. 

You meet up with your friends, enjoy the moment, and the last thing on your mind is your dog’s behavior. 

They get to enjoy this moment, too, because you put in the work to train them 💪🏻

This might sound like a far off dream at the moment, but I assure you, it’s POSSIBLE.

I am really trying to understand why folks cannot say NO to their dog. Why they allow their dog to keep misbehaving, doing dangerous things, running the household? is it that folks actually think dogs are supposed to be primarily misbehaved? is it a self esteem issue and you actually can't set down rules and boundaries as you dont think your dog will love you? what is it?

Why are we so strict about the small stuff?

Because it’s really the BIG stuff…

Take Ares for example in this video.

Shes a HIGHLY fearful, anxious dog, and one of her biggest problems is not being able to maintain a proper heel position. 

You see how she tends to get lost at the end of the leash, circle around, scanning for things to “worry” about. And that’s the last thing we need a skittish dog doing.

Instead, we work on this minute “hiccup” until it’s no longer an issue. 

“Well so what if she spins in a circle?”

We know it’s more than that. We know that means there is a dog who Is not truly in tune with us. Her mind is somewhere else. 

So by focusing on this problem and cleaning it up, you see Ares become much more focused on Courtney and her overall attitude is better too.

Whenever we are rehabbing fearful dogs, we look at the WHOLE picture…

Will cleaning up her turns in heel transfer to her behavior elsewhere? Definitely. Because we’ve done it and seen it happen SO many times before. 

The small stuff just snowballs into the big stuff. Always remember that. 

And if you’re struggling with a dog like Ares, you’re not alone. We’re seeing dogs riddled with fear more than ever these days. 

That’s why we put together the “rehabbing a fearful dog course” where you can see our step by step methods for how we train and rehab dogs with intense fear.

Many stories are made up out there that implementing structure, rules and boundaries into your dog’s life will make them misbehave more, or ruin your relationship. And it’s all just simply not true.

Dogs NEED guidance. They don’t come into this world just automatically knowing what to do. And it’s the responsibility of a dog owner to show their pet both sides of the coin. Teach your dogs what you want AND what you don’t want.

Dogs need the whole story. Dogs need consistency. Dogs need routine and structure. 

Dogs have needs that are vastly different than our own, so it’s up to us to make sure we are truly meeting them.

Let’s perfect that heel 🤩

We call this exercise “closing the gap” or “find my leg”

Basically, we intentionally create space between us and the dog, so that we can use remote pressure to help the dog close the gap. 

By doing repeated reps of this, the dog learns: “if I just move toward my handlers leg, that little sensation goes away”

Thus, creating a dog who is very handler aware and always staying within a nice bubble beside us 🙌🏻

Lots of “I heard this and that” out there. Not a lot of practical application.

Don’t listen to the people who haven’t accomplished the things you want to do.

We definitely use tools because we train for our clients, not our ego. 

we see this phrase floating around all the time

And we get messages from so many newly-starting-out-trainers, AND dog owners, who feel *defeated* after hearing this from some gatekeeper on the internet. 

Our training program has always been highly tool friendly (for good reason)

And suddenly?

Within the last few years, people are being shamed more than EVER for how they choose to train their dogs. 

WE are told regularly how inept we are as trainers because we “rely” on tools 🙄 

At the end of the day, we aren’t moving in with our clients to keep their dogs’ behavior sharp for them 🙃

In order for us to be successful, we need to set owners up for long-term success, too. And that involves utilizing tools that will *pretty much* take all the guess work out of it for them 💯

We know, and we’re sure you know, that it IS possible to train a dog without prong and e-collars. 

But as dog trainers, we’re not ignorant to the fact that most people typically don’t spend every waking moment training their dogs—they have jobs, lives, kids, and households to run.

Do you really want to spend 6+ months working on something that can be accomplished in 6 DAYS? 👀

So your dog is reactive on the leash…

Lunging, barking, causing a scene and you’re afraid your dog might hurt someone, themselves, or you. 

You’re now walking at odd hours, avoiding busy areas, and ducking behind shrubbery to prevent chaos from breaking loose. 

You’ve tried so many techniques and nothing is working. 

That’s most likely because you’re putting your efforts into the wrong methods. 

Dog training isn’t one size fits all, but most bad behaviors will not stop by “teaching the dog something else”

That’s like if you learn a new language you will suddenly forget your primary one? It doesn’t work that way. 

Teaching your dog something new doesn’t resolve the real issue: reactivity. 

Instead, you need to correct that behavior, stop it in its tracks. 

And no, your dog won’t think the correction came from the trigger (that’s just a lie you’ve been told) dogs are smart enough to know that their actions cause a reaction AKA punishment or reward. Their environment has nothing to do with the consequences. 

Once you stop the explosive behavior, now you can move on to your more proactive training like obedience and counter conditioning, which is where Bonnie is at currently. 

She’s getting successful exposure in, she’s learning other dogs aren’t a threat, and most importantly, she’s learning NOT to explode on the walk. She’s patterning good behavior now, albeit a bit stressful for her. 

She’s in the “middle” of rehab. And there’s not much that’s pretty about it. We are breaking YEARS of patterned behaviors for her. 

But we’ve done it so much, we know she’ll come out on the other side a much happier, a much more free, and a much more confident dog. 

If you’re struggling with leash reactivity, life CAN get better. 

Our chaos to control course shows the whole process on how we stop reactivity, train what we want, and get dogs out into the world to live truly fulfilling lives with their owners!

Wake the F#CK up w/Jeff- why the rush with training 

so many folks love to post about whats the rush to train your dog, you should take your time and build a relationship...ummm....yeah but we do and do it rather quickly as well as have a well trained and well behaved dog, meanwhile your dog is still an asshole, but hey, it meets your emotional needs so that makes you an expert and gives you permission to blast trainers who get results

When your dog is truly trained, it shouldn’t matter what leash or collar they’re wearing. 

Do tools expedite the process and make communication clearer? Yep. But eventually you should get to a point where tools are just, there. Not really doing anything other than becoming a “just in case”

Poe is with us for a 4 week board and train here in Florida to work on his overall state of mind and obedience. 

He came in out of control and knowing pretty much no commands (reliably) 

Notice how much leash we give him at this point in training. He’s free to make whatever choices he wants, and yet, he chooses to do the right thing and listen to his trainer under voice control. 

This isn’t by chance or because “he’s being forced to”. It’s because he’s a trained dog. 

No tool will MAKE a dog do something they don’t want to do. Period. 

Dog training is a process that should involve changing the dog’s thought process enough to make them WANT to make the right choice.

We create self aware dogs, not robots. 

We create dogs who can live huge, fulfilled lives with their families. 

We create dogs who are not just doing “tricks” on cue, but who fully embody a lifestyle their owners choose to live with them. 

THAT is what dog training is to us. 

You can have a fully trained dog, a life that feels free, and a healthy balance of love and structure with your dog 

It’s all possible with *training*. 

Our Green to Graduate Program is the playbook of everything we do and preach here. 

If you want your life with your dog to feel effortless and a lot less chaotic…check out the course on solidk9academy.com

Dogs are creatures of their environment. 

Let’s take the standard highly aroused, no manners dog who is friendly as can be, but doesn’t listen and “rules the roost”.

Chances are, this dog would do great with some proper training, structure and leadership. We work with these dogs all the time. 

The thing is- these dogs behave this way because they’re allowed to. It’s as simple as that. 

Dogs are selfish by nature, and they will do things that are self rewarding. Jumping on people, chewing furniture, barking at stuff outside—it’s fun and games. And all easy to stop or change. 

The issue often lies within the dog/human relationship. The owners might feel “bad” for disciplining their dogs, or have been told every lie in the book about how wrong it is to do so. So instead they all struggle for possibly the lifetime of the dog. 

Humans are also creatures of habits, and if our own habits are encouraging bad behaviors, then it becomes a vicious cycle. 

The dog misbehaves, the owner feels bad, the owner gives MORE freedom, more exercise, more fun, more love because that’s what they’re told to do. Instead of just enforcing rules and correcting all the nonsense, the dog just does it more. 

The cycle of self rewarding behavior continues until a breaking point is typically reached. 

Then the owners might seek help, and the right trainer can get results that seem like “magic” when all we do is use an approach that makes sense to the dog. 

We are fair, clear and consistent with our messaging. We don’t allow bad behaviors, we stop them. We reward what we want. OUR attitude and relationship with the dog is built on mutual respect, not one sided as many dog/owner relationships are. 

We get the results we do because we, the humans, know that our behavior contributes to the dog’s long-term success. 

We educate our clients on these concepts and then eventually, they’re successful too 

The changes in your dog always always always begin with YOU.

Don’t keep your dog from their triggers ❌

So often dog owners are avoiding every little thing that sets their dogs off:

The vacuum or broom 🧹 

The cats 🐱 

The cars 🚗 

The bikes 🚴 

When does it end? 

When your life is so small you’re taking walks on the back yard or at 3am? 🌚 

Instead, work your dog THROUGH their fears and anxiety. ✅ 

Teach them how to cope. 

It will be the greatest gift you ever give them (and yourself) 🎁 

And you’re probably thinking “ok but HOW?” 

“I’m telling my dog no” 
“I’m redirecting them around triggers” 
“I’m trying to change the association to it”

But the easiest way is to give your dog a solid obedience foundation. We mean rock solid. 

Like REAL obedience that you can communicate no matter what is going on 

And you just leverage that obedience to help the dog work through the issue.

The best example being 👉 the place command 

If your dog is scared or reactive to the vacuum, have your dog hold place while you vacuum. If they try to attack or run away, just hold them accountable for the command. Teach them place means place, and you stay put. 

Build their stress threshold. Watch them overcome their fears and how that transfers to EVERYTHING else. 

It’s the best advice we could ever give you because we do it every single day successfully. 

⭐️ This ONE Tip will change your life with your dog. Seriously.

If your dog struggles around stimuli, just know…

Shit happens. Even to us as trainers. 

A good example is you’re walking your dog at the park and your dog suddenly starts triggering on birds or squirrels. 

They’re blowing through corrections and quite frankly, don’t give a shit. 

What to do? 

Rather than let them explode and practice really terrible behavior, get them to a more quiet spot and do drills. 

Is this the answer to “solving” reactivity? Absolutely not. 

But in the beginning we’d rather keep sessions successful vs allowing the dog to practice the unwanted behaviors.

So take a step back if you need to in order to regroup. 

Getting frustrated and escalating the situation helps no one.

Rajah is with us for b&t and we’ve been doing sessions with his owner weekly to make sure he respects her and their relationship as much as he does us. 

Dog-owner association is the most important factor in it all. 

If the dog doesn’t believe their owner, then everything falls apart. 

For years, our client hasn’t been able to walk her dog without fear or massive anxiety about how her dog would react toward people and dogs. 

This clip is from our first session in their neighborhood where Rajah has a history of lunging and being reactive on the leash. 

Showing clients what success feels and looks like is what gives them the confidence to keep it going 🩵

E collars are your invisible leash, stop being inconsistent when it comes to your dog wearing it ‼️

❌Whenever we hear folks talk about them like they’re these inhumane pieces of equipment, it just shows the lack of knowledge about them. 

And ultimately, this fear around the tool is what’s hindering so many dog owners and dogs. 

They’re being put on when the dog is “bad” and treated as a last resort. When really, they can be the most proactive training tool. And it’s a shame they’ve gotten the reputation they have now. 

👉When you learn how to properly condition and train on a remote collar, your world expands. 

👉Your dog gets more freedom. 

👉You can have silent and impactful conversations with your dog 

E collars are basically a leash that isn’t attached to you, so you can keep your dog safe in any given moment ✅ 

There are probably a thousand different ways to use e collars, but fully training your dog to understand them in multiple contexts is really the kindest thing you could ever do for them. 

✅Eventually the tool just becomes like your seatbelt in the car. Just sits there, doing nothing, but when push comes to shove… it’s there for you when it’s needed. 

❌We don’t train dogs to comply because they’ve been “shocked” (another huge lie out there) 

✅We train dogs to listen to verbal cues first and foremost. 

The remote collar just supplements the work and the thousands of repetitions it took to teach the dog in the first place. It’s an additional step in the process. Not a “lazy way out.”

How to ruin your dog’s training: 

Get rushed by an untrained, out of control dog. 

“But he’s friendly!!” 

Well, most dogs we know don’t appreciate random, out of control dogs rushing them at full speed while barking. 

(MOST dogs perceive that as a threat and will respond accordingly) 

The dogs who are being rushed don’t know the intention of the strange dog. 

Applying that logic “oh mine is friendly so it’s fine!” to dogs is just irresponsible. 

Friendly does not give a dog a free pass to cause mayhem and do whatever they want.

Let’s call it what it is: a training failure.

Ever see those videos of kids climbing all over dogs and it goes viral for being “cute?” *cringe* 🙄 

When it comes to kids and dogs, BOTH need to be advocated for. 

For some reason, it’s common for children to rush up to dogs and try to pet them. But this is actually a huge “no” in our world. And it’s not just because we work with dangerous dogs.

It’s because even the friendliest dogs should be left alone while they’re in command, or training to be neutral. 

There’s a time and place for everything. 

But if a dog is resting and minding its own business, it’s best to just let sleeping does lie. 

So many bites could be prevented if more people knew how to just exist with dogs, and more dogs knew how to just exist around stimuli. 

It’s a double edged sword. And we train dogs to be as neutral as possible for a reason. 

But every dog has its limits, and that’s why educating adults and children, and setting boundaries around the dog will ultimately be the best way to keep everyone safe.

What should your day with your dog look like outside of training and exercise? 

How do you LIVE with your dog?

Give your dog a job to do while inside the house too, AKA place duration.

Teach your dogs place!!! It’s a game changer for them.

Does affection hurt or help your dog❓

A classic example of affection making things WORSE is:

Struggling with a reactive, overly aroused dog❓

Here’s 3 mistakes you might be making:

👉You’re always holding your dog back! All that leash tension tends to create more conflict and ramp your dog up more. Instead, give your dog *some* leash (within reason) allow them to make a choice (right or wrong) and then give them information based on that choice. There comes a point in every dog’s training where we have to “set them up to fail” so we know for sure if they’re capable of making good decisions on their own. 

👉You’re not addressing the small stuff. If your dog is constantly breaking commands, sniffing and taking its sweet time on a recall, turning its back on you to stare at triggers, this ALL matters. It’s never just about the leash reactivity. It’s everything combined. All the small conversations you have with your dog throughout the day stack.

👉You’re not giving your dog enough information to instill clear boundaries. Lots of times, owners hold back on giving dogs meaningful corrections/information out of fear of “hurting their dogs feelings” meanwhile, the dog is confused and lacking the clarity it really needs. Giving your dog information that it understands is one of the best things you could ever do for them. And it makes the bond stronger.

Does your dog struggle with anxiety in the crate❓

It’s a common issue that we see in so many dogs, and usually happens by pure accident. 

Most dogs enjoy crates once they’re trained to go in one, but it’s the way they enter and exit the crate that make a difference in their state of mind, AND how the crate is utilized. 

👉we NEVER use a crate as punishment. It’s never “bad dog go to your kennel”. Kennels are for calming. For sleeping. For safety. They’re a good thing for the dogs we work with 

👉we use crates throughout the day. Even if it’s for 20 minutes while we shower or just need to give the dog downtime. We don’t associate the crate with “I’m leaving!” Only. Dogs pick up patterns. And if you’re only using a crate when you leave, the dog will figure it out. 

👉we don’t allow dogs to practice neurotic behavior in the kennel like spinning, whining or barking. The kennel is for relaxing. That’s the association we want. 

👉we practice a lot of drills with the kennel. Sending the dog in, calling them out, having them lie down with the door open. This all shows the dog is basically just another place for them to chill and it takes away the “novelty” around it. 

Cayde used to have EXTREME kennel anxiety, whining, and anticipatory behavior inside the kennel. 

After his board and train with us he’s learning it’s just a place to go and chill 🙌🏻

This has come through weeks of reconditioning the kennel and changing his association with it.

Have friends or family visiting with their dogs this holiday season? 🎄 🎁 

Keep reading for our best practices on how to create calmness amongst the chaos 👇 

1. Crate training!! Every dog should have the skills to hang out in a kennel if need be. Crates are great for keeping dogs safe, while still allowing them to be a part of everything. We keep crates in the common area for a reason. It’s great for socialization and teaching dogs how to be neutral around high distractions. 

2. don’t be afraid to set ground rules for your relatives and their dogs. It’s your house, and nobody wants to be stressed out and arguing over the dogs through the holidays. 

3. Keep the dogs on a schedule. Dogs love predictability. Keep a routine for feeding, exercise, downtime, and “free” time. It’s ok to have the dogs crate and rotate. No need for them to ever directly interact. 

4. If you do choose to do some activities together, always start with a leashed walk. Walking is a great way for dogs to exist and “meet” without actually needing to greet one another. 

Remember: rules, structure and boundaries are the key to success with all dogs! (Family too 😂)

We Hope you all have a wonderful last week of 2023, and that this tip saves your sanity!

Dogs don’t need to “meet” to coexist peacefully. 

When you have relatives’ dogs in your house during the holidays, or any time of year for the matter, it’s NOT necessary for them to meet eachother. 

Dogs don’t need to be friends. 

Dogs don’t ever need to sniff or get in each others space. 

What you can do though, is integrate them through migration—AKA a walk! 

That’s the best way for dogs to “meet” since it’s low pressure and they can work on existing vs interacting. 

Walks are structured, the dogs typically understand there are rules around the walk, and there’s a lot less chance of an accident happening. 

Dogs also have superior senses of smell, so they don’t need to sniff each others butts in these scenarios lol. 

They are well aware that the dog walking next to them is a dog, and it’s ok not to force sniffing either. 

Let the dogs just exist, get some exercise, and learn that neutral and calm behavior are the recipe for success. 

🎄The holidays are stressful enough! Don’t let the dogs add any more pressure.

Does “punishment” put a bad taste in your mouth❓

❌Maybe you’ve been told that correcting unwanted behavior in your dog will “make things much worse.”

❌Or that it will destroy your relationship with your dog. 

We’ve heard it all. Our clients have been told it all. And for some reason, after thousands of dogs trained with every behavioral issue imaginable, we just aren’t seeing it happen. 

👉Of course, you should be spending the majority of the time teaching your dog what you DO want, but adding more and more behaviors does not suddenly remove the bad ones. 

They’re always there until you give your dog a consequence that motivates them enough to stop doing them!

👉Call it “suppression” if you want. But any respectable, functioning human suppresses many behaviors every day. 

It’s NORMAL to control your impulses. Humans and dogs SHOULD have this skillset. 

❌If you’re not teaching your dog both “yes” and “no”, you’re withholding a massive piece of the equation from them, and it’s really not fair. 

If you truly want to give your dog a fulfilling life, be able to trust them in the real world and inside your home, take them everywhere with you— then you need to get comfortable with correcting unwanted behaviors unemotionally and appropriately timed.

Many stories are made up out there that implementing structure, rules and boundaries into your dog’s life will make them misbehave more, or ruin your relationship. And it’s all just simply not true. 

All we see are dogs get BETTER from training while their relationship with their owners becomes stronger. 

Dogs NEED guidance. They don’t come into this world just automatically knowing what to do. And it’s the responsibility of a dog owner to show their pet both sides of the coin. Teach your dogs what you want AND what you don’t want. 

That’s the only way to have clear and effective communication. 

Dogs need the whole story. Dogs need consistency. Dogs need routine and structure. 

Correcting unwanted behaviors just teaches the dog a level of expectation which will allow them to do MORE with you, and live a more fulfilled life. 

Dogs have needs that are vastly different than our own, so it’s up to us to make sure we are truly meeting them.

E collars are your invisible leash, not a torture device.

Whenever we hear folks talk about them like they’re these inhumane pieces of equipment, it just shows the lack of knowledge about them. 

And ultimately, this fear around the tool is what’s hindering so many dog owners and dogs. 

When you learn how to properly condition and train on a remote collar, your world expands. 

Your dog gets more freedom. 

You can have silent and impactful conversations with your dog 

E collars are basically a leash that isn’t attached to you, so you can keep your dog safe in any given moment.

There are probably a thousand different ways to use e collars, but fully training your dog to understand them in multiple contexts is really the kindest thing you could ever do for them. 

Eventually the tool just becomes like your seatbelt in the car. Just sits there, doing nothing, but when push comes to shove… it’s there for you when it’s needed. 

We don’t train dogs to comply because they’ve been “shocked” (another huge lie out there) 

We train dogs to listen to verbal cues first and foremost.

People often love the results but hate the process. Meanwhile, dogs and owners are having a great time knowing they have full off leash control and reliability 🙌🏻

Socialization does not mean allowing your dog to interact with every person it encounters. 

To us, and for all of our clients, socialization always begins with existence first. 

We do this for many reasons:

👉we don’t want dogs thinking that it’s ok to expect affection or greetings from everyone they meet. We want our dogs to be handler aware— meaning they remain neutral to their environment and pay attention to their main handler. This helps in ALL parts of the relationship, including public access skills. 

👉some dogs actually don’t enjoy affection, especially from strangers. The worst thing to do to a nervous or stranger shy dog is force affection on them. Then they will just learn that biting or growling works to keep the strangers away from them. A habit we do not want dogs practicing. Instead, we advocate for the dogs and ask them to just lie down, be calm, and we will keep them safe. This allows for them to be a lot more comfortable in their environment. 

👉dogs are not stuffed animals. Anything can go sideways, even with a highly trained dog. Many times, the humans asking to do the petting come on too strong and get the dog ramped up, or cause them to break command etc. it’s just not fair to the dogs, and also, it’s not necessary for a dog to be pet by every person. 

👉your dog. Your rules. You can choose whether or not you want your dog to interact with strangers. Period. We love teaching neutrality in public though, because it helps with the dogs state of mind and teaches them healthy boundaries.

How to work through crate anxiety:

👉Contrary to what you’ve been told, creating a positive association with a crate (when the dog already hates the crate) doesn’t work. 

👉You can give them the softest bed, the best treats, all the puzzle toys in the world, and it will NOT stop barking, whining, or attempts to break out. 

👆All of the above is considered “unwanted behavior”, and thus, it can be corrected. 

❌People will tell you “well that will make it worse.” But how can you make it worse, when the association is ALREADY terrible??

✅Instead, correct the nonsense off the bat, and then work on getting the dog into a better headspace. 

👉No dog, who’s in an anxious + aroused state of mind is going to be receptive to learning. You need to address state of mind first and foremost.

When you have dogs who have a history of guarding, reactivity, and even dog fights (both Marley and Hulk do) it’s best to set the tone and create clear boundaries from the start. 

Since Marley (yellow dog) and Hulk (grey dog) will be kennel neighbors, we do not want any nonsense breaking out— like barrier aggression or even side eyeing eachother. 

It’s all the small conversations we have with dogs that stack. 

Rather than waiting for sh*t to hit the fan with these two, and then needing to give a big correction, we have subtle, quiet conversations from the go. 

Notice how Marley was just paying a little too much attention to Hulk, which could have easily made him feel uncomfortable in that situation, and then triggered him into a reaction. Instead of allowing it to escalate, we just give Marley and Hulk some low level communication to mind their own business. 

The kennel is a place for relaxing, not trying to sniff other dogs, or guard, or push boundaries. 

So when we have the conversations sooner, rather than later, this allows us to whisper to the dogs and have some very informative conversations that will lay the foundation for everything that’s to come. 

Kennel manners matter! It’s the first thing every dog learns when they come through our training program.

Earned freedom 💯

One major philosophy we follow is that dogs should earn their freedoms inside and outside of the home. 

This isn’t to say “be mean from the start” 🙄 but you should absolutely set some boundaries and rules with your dog before giving them run of the roost. 

Dogs need to understand what’s expected of them, and that their actions have consequences (both postive and negative) 

This gives them a full picture idea of what behaviors are to be repeated (or not) 

This is how you build a true relationship with a dog. One where the respect goes both ways— and you’re not just a door mat to your dog and their bad behaviors.

Dogs that break out of crates, harm themselves in the process, and who can’t be left alone for even ten minutes are not only a risk to themselves, but the people who live with them, too. 

This behavior is called separation anxiety, and every. Single. Day. We are getting DMs, emails, and comments about how much this behavior is destroying peoples’ (and dogs’) lives. 

“I haven’t been able to go on a date night with my s/o since we got this dog.”

“I had to pull my kids from extra-curricular activities because we can’t leave the dog home alone.”

“My dog destroys the crate when left alone, and hurts himself in the process. If he’s not crated, he will eat the window frames.”

“Our dog will howl and bark so loud, my landlord is threatening to evict me.”

These are REAL stories. This is how separation anxiety is affecting families around the world. 

It’s heartbreaking, and we understand how much pain and stress this ONE issue can cause. 

We put it at the top of the “most painful to live with” list— above aggression, believe it or not.

There is so escaping separation anxiety when you’re in the thralls of it. It’s a problem that spills over to every part of your life.

That’s why when people describe It…it’s often accompanied by the words: “suffering” “struggle” “desperation” “trapped”

It’s a crappy way to live with your dog…

And we don’t want that for anyone.

If you’re just “going through the motions” when it comes to training…

Never pushing yourself or your dog past your current thresholds…

Being lax with your general approach to it all and doing the bare minimum…

Then you’re going to find yourself running on a hamster wheel.

Putting in a million more reps with your dog won’t actually get you a better trained dog.

Not until you start asking more of your dog (and yourself).

Get out of your comfort zone. Execute on the training. Push yourself. 

A whole world is waiting out there for you

Getting dogs to exist will always work out better than allowing a free for all from the start. 

Implanting rules, structure and routine will set the dogs up for the most success. 

We’re never in a rush to get dogs to be “friends” we actually don’t care if they ever LOVE each other. We just want them to be able to be neutral. 

Marley (yellow dog) has a history of getting into dog fights, so when we begin her socialization process it’s slow and steady. 

We don’t push her into unwanted interactions that we know would end up in her getting defensive or wanting to attack another dog. 

Instead, we opt for migrating them on walks, training sessions together, etc. and this allows for less pressure all around.

Dogs who master the skill of neutrality are dogs that can do a LOT with their owners. That’s why we focus so much on this.

1. Typically the things you’re resisting are the things that need to be done. Like getting your dog out of your bed, holding them accountable for bad behaviors, and not giving them free run of the house. 

2. Loving your dog out of bad behavior isn’t possible. Loving your dog into good behavior isn’t possible. Dogs need rules, structure and boundaries just as much as kids do. It’s not fair to withhold certain information from them simply because it feels “good” to you 

3. Dogs are actually way smarter than you think and know how to take advantage of situations. Ever notice your dog behaves a certain way for you, and entirely different for another person? That’s not just a coincidence… 

4. I am a huge advocate of exercise and mental stimulation for dogs. BUT I don’t think exercise solves behavioral issues. “A tired dog is a good dog” is a lie. A tired dog is just tired for now, and will be right back to its nonsense once rested. 

5. Sit, down, come, heel etc are all worthless commands if your dog can’t do them for extended periods of time around high levels of distractions. Just because your dog can do a “down” for 5 seconds in the kitchen, does not mean your dog truly knows the down command. If you want training that fits your lifestyle, you need to make training a part of your lifestyle.
